name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the report by Joëlle Bergeron, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on penitentiary systems and prison conditions (2015/2062 (INI)) (A8-0251 / 2017) The subject is close to me,because under communism I myself was briefly a political prisoner.I will therefore conduct this debate with interest.

name: Joëlle Bergeron
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the floor to present this own-initiative report on penitentiary systems and living conditions in prisons in Europe. Like some of you, I had preconceptions about prisons, the prison population and prison staff. This is why I went to see concretely what is happening on the ground, in France and in other Member States, in order to take into account the opinions of all those involved: prisoners, staff, prison administration, prison services. integration and probation, ministerial officials. I would like to especially thank Mrs Chinnici and Mrs Hautala who allowed me to visit establishments in their respective countries, that is to say Italy and Finland. I myself have made a large number of visits to France. Those working in the prison world have given us a lot of time to make us understand their situation, the difficulties they face, and they have shown us that there are other ways than "all prison". The situation and the living conditions of prisoners are a real human problem. I would like to remind you of a few figures: in 2014, according to Council of Europe figures, there were just over 1.6 million prisoners in Europe. This figure includes people in prison after conviction, but also those in pre-trial detention. Still according to the Council of Europe, the prison population rate fell by 7% between 2013 and 2014. However, overcrowding nonetheless remains a central issue in prison systems since, although the prison occupancy rate is from 117% in Europe, it is over 200% in remand centers, and I remind you that these establishments mix convicts and people awaiting conviction. Prison overcrowding leads to deplorable living conditions which amount to inhuman and degrading treatment within the meaning of Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. It is on the basis of this text and its recommendations that this report has been drawn up. In addition to overcrowding, there are all the problems linked to the dilapidated prison structures, lack of medical care and monitoring, violence between prisoners, but also between prisoners and prison staff. These staff that I have met, although often understaffed and feel poorly regarded, carry out their mission with impressive professionalism and humanity. This direct contact with people in the field, but also with legal experts and associations that follow these prison issues, allowed me to realize the complexity of this subject and the need to address all facets of prison life. , namely in particular: the living conditions and care of detainees; protection of the most vulnerable (sick, women and minors); the maintenance of family ties for prisoners; education, instruction and reintegration; the prevention, identification and treatment of radicalization; the training and working conditions of prison staff. All of these issues are interrelated, and it is the duty of Member States to develop prison policies that respect the dignity of each person without neglecting effective and appropriate treatment of delinquency. The facts are stubborn and prove that the "all prisoner" system may not be the most effective, and in some cases even be counterproductive. This is why it seems to me necessary to encourage the good practices existing in certain Member States, and in particular in the Scandinavian countries, which privilege the prevention, the alternative sentences, the medico-social care of the prisoners and the preparation for the reintegration through prison systems open. When incarceration is essential, we must keep in mind that the mission of the prison is also the preparation for the reintegration of prisoners to avoid a recidivism which, in some cases, can reach more than 50% within five years. follow the exit. Successful social reintegration reduces recidivism. The fact that I am not partisan at all prison does not mean that I am naive or lax. My design aims to give real meaning to incarceration. We must protect vulnerable prisoners from the most dangerous prisoners if we want to avoid the risks of radicalization and the fall into organized crime. The alternative measures make it possible to avoid contact between petty offenders and the most dangerous prisoners. In conclusion, I will tell you that I am aware that all minds have not yet been trained in this more humanistic conception of the prison universe. I hope you have time to move on this matter. Mentalities must change, political wills must be asserted without electoral demagoguery. This subject concerns us all. Prison reflects the social and moral state of our society, but also our conception of basic human rights.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for their report. Although detention conditions are primarily the responsibility of Member States, who have agreed to respect the existing Council of Europe standards on the matter, the Commission attaches great importance to respect for the fundamental rights of persons in detention in the European Union. Improving prison conditions has become a priority at EU level because, among other reasons, they affect the efficient operation of EU mutual recognition instruments such as the European Arrest Warrant and because of the danger of radicalisation in prisons. The Commission therefore fully supports this own—initiative report from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  Increasing prisons’ capacity is not the sole solution to overcrowding as the prison population tends to rise at the same rate as prison capacity. The focus should therefore rather be on the improvement of existing penitentiary structures, many of which in different Member States are obsolete and do not function properly in terms of rehabilitation services. To facilitate that we have undertaken a mapping exercise to see how different EU funds could be employed to improve the situation in prisons in the EU. I have raised this several times with Justice Ministers, who are not always fully aware of the possibilities the European funds on regional and cohesion policy offer in that regard. But I would also like to mention the importance of alternatives to detention. Member States have committed themselves under the EU Framework Decisions I just mentioned to accept alternative sentences, both in the pre—trial and the post-trial stage. Even if the Framework Decisions oblige the Member States to adopt a certain number of alternatives, for these alternatives to be used you need a certain practice and a developed probation structure. That is what is lacking in many Member States. This is an area where a lot could be done at EU level. Some Member States are already well advanced in this area and others could learn from them. We could help to exchange best practices among Member States. The last point I would like to touch upon is radicalisation. Some of the individuals involved in terrorist attacks in Europe were allegedly radicalised while serving prison sentences for other crimes. We need to find ways to prevent such violent radicalisation in our prisons and to help radicalised individuals to find other paths when they leave prison. Following our Ministerial Conference on the matter in 2015 and the linked Council conclusions, our priority is to use all available means, including financial, to support Member States to speed up the setting up of projects such as the development of deradicalisation and rehabilitation programmes in and outside prisons, risk assessment tools and training schemes for prison staff, judges and prosecutors in the Member States. To this effect we made EUR 6.5 million available in 2015 and 2016 under the Justice Programme and continue to do so in 2017 and 2018. Judicial training will remain an important factor. Prison staff and probation officers are covered by the judicial training course.  I would also like to remind you of the Commission’s High—Level Expert Group on radicalisation that will allow for further discussion with Member States on the possible options for further and future more structured cooperation mechanisms in this area. One of the priority topics to be discussed is indeed radicalisation in prisons. I am planning to come back to this issue of radicalisation in prisons at a high-level meeting before the end of the year.  The Commission also pays particular attention to the children of parents in prison, of whom it is estimated that there are about 800 000 in the EU. Therefore, this year’s European Forum on the Rights of the Child, which will take place from 6 to 8 November 2017, will have a focus on the deprivation of liberty of children and alternatives to detention. Furthermore, the situation of the children of parents in prison will also be addressed as one of the main topics. Thank you again for your report as it supports our efforts in tackling the various aspects of detention in the EU.

name: Barbara Matera
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, women make up 4.5% of the prisoners in EU prisons, a number which fluctuates around 25,000. On numerous occasions they are new mothers and mothers of children. That is why I stressed in my report the need for European prisons to take into account the special needs of these women. I find it important that Member States ensure that all the hygienic and health needs of women are met, with regard to gynecological health, pre- and postnatal care, and to take appropriate measures to address high levels of disproportionation, especially in use of drugs in prisons. To address these problems, I requested the need for female prisons to be equipped with predominantly female staff, in particular for the special attention that must be given to pregnant women in prison, during and after childbirth, providing adequate spaces for breastfeeding, for qualified and specialized nursing assistance. Following the principle that the minor does not have to pay for the responsibilities of the mother, I therefore thought it appropriate to suggest a reflection on alternative models of detention. We are not asking for penalty discounts but simply more humane conditions.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague Joëlle Bergeron on her excellent work. Thank you very much. In 2014, there were more than half a million prisoners in European Union prisons, a figure that includes people sentenced to serve a final sentence and those who have been charged with a crime and are in preventive detention who, according to Eurostat data, they are more than 20% of the total prison population. While the conditions of detention and the management of prisons are the responsibility of the Member States, the Union must also play a necessary role in safeguarding the fundamental rights of detainees and in creating the European area of ​​freedom, security and justice. There are considerable differences between the judicial and penitentiary systems used in the countries of the Union, particularly with regard to the adoption of alternative measures, detention and substitutive sentences for short-term sentences. This House passed, in 99, an important resolution on the conditions of prisons in the Union, adaptations and substitution penalties. After almost 20 years, we are again discussing this issue and many of the premises and situations identified then are the same as those we discussed here today. Dear colleagues, I believe that there is a need for convergence in the ways of exercising justice in the Member States, despite the difficulties that this entails. Today, it is possible to see serious problems in the prison system, as the Commissioner said, of prison overcrowding, consumption of illicit substances, an alarming rate of suicide numbers and the radicalization in many of the Union prisons, which are very worrying phenomena that require particular attention. For all these reasons, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the institutions of the Union should support technically and economically, as much as possible, the improvement of prison systems and conditions, especially in Member States facing serious financial difficulties.The situation in Europe's prisons is worrying and the European Parliament has an undeniable role in reversing this situation.

name: Caterina Chinnici
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like first of all to thank Mrs Bergeron for her excellent work and all the shadow rapporteurs. As emerged during the visits carried out by the rapporteur herself in some prisons and as was rightly highlighted in the report, overcrowding, degrading living conditions, the lack of training activities, the sometimes shortage of specialized personnel are unfortunately common to several States members of the Union. However, the text does not limit itself to highlighting the existing malfunctions in European prison systems, but also identifies guidelines and good practices to be implemented in the prisons of the Member States. And while the management of prison systems falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States, the European Union can and must play a key role in safeguarding the fundamental rights of prisoners. The prisoner is first of all a human being, holder of rights, whose dignity must always be guaranteed and safeguarded. Ensuring decent living conditions for every prisoner is not only a humanitarian obligation, but is the indispensable prerequisite for a recovery path that finds in access to alternative measures, the most suitable tool to allow resocialization and reintegration into civil life. The data collected during the drafting of the report confirm precisely this thesis: in fact, the convicts who have benefited from alternative measures have much lower recidivism rates than those who serve the entire sentence in detention. The growing use of alternative penalties or community measures, however, will have to be accompanied by the necessary reforms of the judicial, educational and social systems, as you yourself, Commissioner stressed. However, the success of re-educational processes also requires the indispensable contribution of the prison police staff, always at the forefront of relations with prisoners.Adequate resources, support and appropriate training must be guaranteed to the prison police, especially in the light of the new challenges facing the prison systems of the Member States.I am thinking in particular of the phenomenon of radicalization, which cannot be adequately prevented and countered without adequate monitoring and specific programs of penitentiary treatment.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: for the ECR Group. - Sir. Chairman! It is not and will never be a primary concern for me to provide better relations with Europe's criminals, both because it is first and foremost a task to be carried out by the Member States and secondarily because we should be on the side of the victims first and foremost. That said, it is incredibly important that the Member States assume their responsibilities. It would be better if all Member States, for example, took back its own convicted citizens, as the rules prescribe, quickly and without hesitation. It would be good if the European Arrest Warrant came to work in a better and more satisfactory way, and we can only appeal to all Member States, incl. those who have been involved for a little less than ten years are living up to the common commitments made to have a well-functioning, open and transparent labor market, where we have confidence that we are cooperating against crime. That is the main task of European politicians, both here in the House and in the various national parliaments.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in some EU Member States detention conditions fail to comply with international law and human rights standards, especially those included in the European Convention on Human Rights and the case law of the European Court of Human Rights. I welcome that this resolution is addressing the main problems prisons in the EU face such as overpopulation, radicalisation of prisoners, outdated facilities, lack of medical care, violence, lack of resources, poor staff levels and violations of fundamental rights of prisoners.  Member States should exchange best practices and follow recommendations, especially concerning the modernisation of prisons and the development of educational and practical skills to facilitate reintegration. In addition, special attention should be paid to vulnerable, elderly and disabled prisoners and the specific needs of women as well as children. In this regard, it is vital to improve the training of prison staff also with the aim of countering radicalisation in prisons.  As a Member of the Committee on Women’s Rights, I would like to address the importance of hygiene standards within prisons and the provision of health services such as pre- and post-natal care. In this regard, it is important to highlight that the automatic separation of a mother from her child creates an additional penalty and can cause major emotional disturbances. Therefore, I call on the Member States to enable mothers to stay with their children as long as possible by providing adequate spaces for breastfeeding and extending visiting and telephone time between children and their parents.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for her work. The human rights of all citizens must be guaranteed. Those of the prisoners as well. On too many occasions, living conditions in prison amount to inhuman or degrading treatment. It is very good news that this report is based on the principle of reintegration. It speaks of the fact that preventive detention should be a measure of last resort, that prison is particularly inappropriate, for example, for seriously ill prisoners, and would be the first text of the Union to condemn the prison policy of withdrawal some Member States apply. As a consequence of the policy of dispersion applied by the Spanish and French states, only two of the 314 politically motivated Basque prisoners are in prisons in the Basque Country; twenty-one are seriously ill. This report is a first step in asking the European Commission to regulate the rights of prisoners at the European level and to establish more guarantees.

name: Eva Joly
text: , on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first I would like to pay tribute to my colleague, Mrs Bergeron, for her commitment to this subject. We really feel that it is close to his heart, and rightly so. A big thank you to you. What is prison for? In post-war France, the Amor reform affirmed that it should simultaneously protect society, respect detainees and promote their reintegration. Seventy years later, in France and in the majority of the Member States, it does not fulfill any of these three missions. Prison does not protect society, it is just an illusion of efficiency that especially punishes precarious populations. Our societies increasingly criminalize minor facts and sentence people to prison more often and for longer. This is especially true for petty crimes, while white collar crimes are still widely tolerated and not prosecuted. Incarceration leads to professional and family desocialization, and potentially re-socialization in criminal, even radical delinquent circles. Prison also increases the risk of reoffending. Is this really protecting society? The detainees, far from being respected, are denied in their humanity. The security logic prevailed everywhere, even as crime declined. As a result, the number of detainees has exploded, prison overcrowding has reached new heights and conditions of detention have deteriorated cruelly. Remand centers in France have an average occupancy rate of 170%. How many convictions of the ECHR will it take for reception capacities to be finally respected? When will we agree to decriminalize minor offenses? Finally, the reintegration of prisoners is far from being favored: only 15% of prisoners in France have a job in a remand center, it is very difficult to follow an education there, or even to have access to books, to exercise one's citizenship is an obstacle course.In the absence of real reintegration programs and personalized follow-up, the prison sentence is meaningless.Imprisoning more is therefore less effective in defending society.Other more effective responses exist.Today's own-initiative report makes some good recommendations in this direction.It is up to our governments to draw the consequences.What is prison for in Europe in 2017?To falsely reassure society, certainly not to protect it.Prison today is money wasted for taxpayers, time wasted for prisoners, and time wasted for society.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the fact that the employment rate of prisons in Europe has slightly decreased in recent years, the unease caused by the excessive overcrowding of prisons still remains very serious. A situation that becomes even more dramatic if we consider the age of the vast majority of prisons, the lack of adequate health services, the violence that often occurs in prisons and, last but not least, the very difficult and often underestimated working conditions of prison staff. As already reiterated by this Parliament, the fundamental rights of prisoners must be guaranteed by the national authorities. Therefore, it is necessary that the Member States urgently address the issue of the abuse of pre-trial detention measures, as well as that of alternative measures to detention that favor the re-education and social reintegration of convicted, socially not dangerous. Colleague Bergeron's report has the merit of highlighting the critical aspects of a reality that we are usually used to ignoring, recalling that the compass that must guide us is always respect for fundamental rights and the safeguarding of the human dignity of prisoners. .

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, the Bergeron report is absolutely irrelevant. Bathed in good feelings, he condemns prison overcrowding and recommends developing alternative sentences to prison. You would think you were reading the Taubira law. Surrealistically, the Bergeron report even hopes for "the establishment of a representative democracy in prisons". Faced with this delirium, worthy of the ultra-left, I would like to point out that prison policy falls under the sovereignty of States and not under the competence of the European Union. That is why the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group has tabled an alternative draft resolution calling on states to assume their sovereignty and take two radical measures to reduce prison overcrowding. First, to regain control of their national borders to prevent certain criminals from entering and, second, to enter into bilateral agreements with third countries for foreign detainees to serve their sentences there. Since I have five seconds left, I would like to take this opportunity to point out that my colleague, Christelle Lechevalier, is here today, replacing Marine Le Pen, and to welcome her.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the situation in detention facilities in some Member States is really tragic: overcrowding, staff shortages, outdated facilities. In Greece, we also face the problem of the huge number of foreign prisoners with all that this implies for the prevailing conditions. The report, however, deals only with the living conditions of the detainees. It focuses only on how their sentences will be reduced, ignoring their victims. He does not care about the prison staff whose life and health are in danger every day. The European Union imposed spending cuts on Greece, which resulted in a lack of staff and the inability to build new facilities or modernize existing ones. With the famous "Paraskevopoulos law", the no. 4322/15 for the decongestion of prisons, more than 2,000 prisoners in Greece were released. No one can deny that the bill paid off financially, but after the release we had dozens of convicts who ended up committing criminal acts again. I urge you, therefore, to turn your perspective, support the allocation of new funds and focus on a policy that defends victims, society and those who serve it, and not those who undermine it.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Now I do not hope that this report will end up as a paper aviator in the Commission! There is no doubt that it is the responsibility and competence of the Member States to ensure that things are in order. I think it is worrying, because the Commission is the guardian of the Treaty, that there are countries in Europe, members of the European Union, that are definitely violating Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights one after another. I would like to say that I come from a country, Denmark, where we have this problem in our lives, because the Human Rights Court in 2016 ruled on the place that a detainee must have at his disposal, and the Supreme Court in Denmark on that basis has decided, that four Romanian nationals cannot be extradited to serve their sentences in Romania, as a room of 2-3 m2 cannot be guaranteed. The Supreme Court has therefore ruled that these persons cannot be deported and that it would be contrary to Article 3 of the Convention on Human Rights. It is completely unheard of to have a European extradition arrest where one cannot extradite a man who is to return home and serve 4½ years in Romania due to the fact that one can not ensure the person proper conditions! We have people who have been convicted of human trafficking in Denmark who cannot come to Romania and serve their sentences. We have EU rules that you must receive your own citizens for imprisonment if there is a residual sentence of six months. So here we are with cases where people have been sentenced to longer prison terms and where the country in which the crime was committed hangs on it, because there are EU countries that are not in order in the cases, and this is in my opinion in fact The Commission's responsibility also to point out. If a country can be a member of the EU, it can also ensure that the Convention on Human Rights is respected. In fact, in this case, Romania has lost 89.9% of the cases before the European Court of Human Rights. I think that is shameful, and the Commission should do something about it. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question accordingly Rule 162 (2) of the Rules of Procedure8)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to ask colleague Bendtsen about the social situation of the prisoners.If someone from Romania is imprisoned in Denmark, then of course they also have problems with the language and then do not have the opportunity to rehabilitate themselves in prison.Wouldn't it be a human right that a Romanian also has the right to go to a Romanian prison again, because of course communication could be much better there, and socialization in this sense too?

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Blue card answer.- Yes, I completely agree with that, and therefore I believe that one must ensure that Romanian citizens who have been convicted of crime in Denmark can come home and serve time at home.It is not always so that they want it, because the conditions in the Romanian prisons are as poor as they are at present.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, European statistics show that, on the one hand, the number of women in detention is growing faster than in the case of men and, on the other hand, the recidivism and return rate in Detention may exceed 50% within 5 years of release from prison. I believe that it is beneficial for the European Union to work with the Member States to find common solutions at European level on developing educational and social support in preparation for the release of prisoners, as well as socio-judicial supervision after detention, in order to enable better punishment management, successful social reintegration and a reduction in the risk of recidivism. Given that in many cases women in prison are the sole carers of children, and maintaining family ties is essential, I believe that Member States must ensure that women prisoners have regular contact with their families: by promoting visits, telephone calls and the use of electronic communications. On the other hand, it is necessary to avoid situations in which detainees are placed in prisons scattered throughout the territory and to find solutions that allow detainees who are away from home to be moved closer, in order to avoid violating Article 8 of the Convention. European Convention on Human Rights, namely the right to respect for private and family life. Last but not least, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her approach in this report.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Thank you to Mrs Bergeron for this very fine report. In connection with the debate, however, it is important for me to point out that, in my opinion, there is something missing in the report. There is a lack of our common responsibility for many of our European citizens who are imprisoned in countries outside the European Community under conditions which, in my opinion, give rise to deep, deep concern. These are conditions that border on torture-like conditions. As recently as this month, I had contact with an elderly Danish prisoner named Anker Hansen, who is in terrible conditions in Indonesia. Having not had access to the vital medicine he needs, he is now so crippled that he can no longer walk. He risks dying under those conditions if no action is taken. No matter what a human being has done, no one deserves to rot in a prison far from home in miserable circumstances where cruel and degrading treatment is a part of everyday life. There is a need for the European Parliament to intervene in relation to prisoners where we know that human rights are being violated every single day.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, as someone who has spent thirteen-and-a-half years in prison, I declare an interest in ensuring that prison systems and conditions are upheld to appropriate standards. Irish Republicans were interned without trial and endured awful prison conditions, those who went on hunger strike were vilified by the establishment, some prisoners lost their lives while being force-fed and, in 1981, Bobby Sands and nine other Irish Republican prisoners died on hunger strike. Those days will never be forgotten.  The Good Friday Agreement ensured the release of politically motivated prisoners to advance the peace process, but even in this era of the peace process Derry man Tony Taylor is detained without trial and should be released immediately. Palestinian prisoners are subjected to regular violations of human rights and Basque prisoners are held hundreds of miles from their families, who are unfairly punished by an inhuman dispersal policy. Prison systems must show that human rights are upheld and applied consistently. They should never be used as a weapon by any state. I want to thank the rapporteur for this report.

text: That's a lot, I stayed much shorter.

name: Christelle Lechevalier (ENF).
text: - Mr President, Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, this report constitutes a direct attack on the functioning of justice. Faced with prison overcrowding, which would require the creation of prison places, you propose limiting imprisonment. While the sanction must be applied from the first acts of delinquency to stem recidivism, you encourage laxity. A major problem is missing from this report: the decline of justice. Hundreds of thousands of sentences handed down are not carried out, for lack of space or for convenience, leaving the condemned to drift until they are sentenced to long sentences complicating reintegration. These first sentences not applied are ultimately detrimental to justice, but also to the condemned and especially to the victims, largely forgotten by this text. With the same chimerical vision, you question the preventive imprisonment, essential for the application of justice, to the detriment of past victims and future victims that you create by laxity. For you, convicts are victims of society and repeat offenders are victims of the prison system. For us, it is essential to avoid the spiral of recidivism, by short sentences from the first offenses, the real application of the pronounced judgments, floor sentences to firmly sanction recidivism and imprisonment in the country of origin of foreign prisoners.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, without doubt existing European Union policies, specifically human rights legislation and freedom of movement, are now actively contributing to the problems in prisons, and particularly those in the United Kingdom. No one ever dreamed when devising these so-called European Union pillars that they would be used to support mobile phone usage or drugs delivered by drones, or indeed facilitate the development of radicalisation and extremism, all adding to the enormous pressures on and dangers to prison staff.  It is important, though, to acknowledge that prisoners have broken a social contract and so their incarceration acts as protection for society, as well as punishment of the perpetrator. Overcrowding is a major issue: 5 000 of the 13 000 prisoners in United Kingdom jails are EU citizens. As soon as we can actually achieve a proper programme of deporting those, and not see them protected by European Union human rights legislation, that will go a long way to dealing with overcrowding.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! The quality of a civilization can be recognized primarily by the look of its prisons, the proportion of people imprisoned in the population, whether prisons are geared towards rehabilitation or merely serve a sense of revenge, but above all by whether human rights are under such extreme conditions must be observed. Today's debate on this successful report is therefore very important, and only if prisons develop in this direction will we also become an area of ​​freedom, security and justice. Yes, dear colleagues, there is a public responsibility. Therefore, all efforts in the direction of privatization of the penal system must be rejected. The public interest must be the focus, and it is in the public interest that people are not just locked away, but that they are shown a way back. Only then will we get what we all want: more security.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. President, the latest study on the reality of the penitentiary in the Spanish State, carried out by the network of social organizations in the prison environment is devastating: in the Spanish State there are more prisoners, for longer and for less serious crimes than in the rest of Europe. And that our crime rate is well below the European average. The rate of incarcerated in the Spanish State is 32% above the European average, and the duration of the sentences is more than double this average, and this is because successive reforms of the Penal Code have made our system every harder time. 65% of prisoners have drug addiction problems, and one in four prisoners has mental health problems. In the Spanish state, prisons are being used as a warehouse in which to hide our social problems. Prison should be the last resort. Alternatives to prison, such as mediation for damages caused, community services or treatment outside prison for people with mental health problems or drug addiction are the alternative, and, of course, social justice, the fight against inequality and the strength of public services are the only way to combat social problems.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in one minute, you have to choose your message, and mine will be to consider that deprivation of liberty should be used to protect society. However, today our prison model is no longer suitable. It often produces what it intends to fight, which is crime. I think it's time to question our policy on this and this report does. Never before have there been so many prisoners in European prisons, when prison overcrowding is having devastating effects. However, these prisoners will come out one day. The question of their reintegration is therefore essential. The purpose of prisons is not simply to punish. That’s why we have to ask ourselves what we want, which is a safer society in which former prisoners do not reoffend. Let us take the example of our Scandinavian neighbors, who provide prisoners with decent conditions of detention and who prepare their return to freedom. To effectively fight against recidivism, an innovative prison policy is necessary. Many alternatives to pre-trial detention must be used, but also alternative penalties must be used. It is time to consider prison policy as a means of reintegration into society and not just exclusion at all costs.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, speaking at the end of this debate, I would firstly like to thank the rapporteur for the importance and accuracy of this report and I agree with what my colleagues and colleagues in my group have already said that I they preceded. So I speak of what I have seen and see with my own eyes. Yesterday, Emiliano Puleo, a boy who was detained for months in Hamburg prison, was released from the prison in Hamburg, without having yet received any sentence, any preventive and precautionary sentence. The repression of political dissent is increasingly becoming an emergency in Europe: as I have already reported in a report to the Commissioner, in Italy there is a crime, a denial of fundamental human rights, a form of torture called prison which is life imprisonment. I believe that it is essential that this Parliament take action, use all the power it has at its disposal to guarantee the rights of prisoners, the rights of trans people in prison. I say this as shadow rapporteur of the opinion of the FEMM committee, I think that from this point of view this report makes us take a step forward.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, in the last legislature, as president of the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and the Interior, I had the honor of presiding over a European mission to analyze the prison system, the issue that concerns us and which I dealt with as minister of Justice of Spain during my mandate. There are 1,600,000 people deprived of their liberty, and the way in which a society treats persons deprived of liberty is, without a doubt, a measure of the quality of that society and of its democracy. That is why we have to worry that overcrowding, which is especially sensitive in some countries - Portugal, Greece, France, Belgium, Hungary, Italy and also my country, Spain - is not the source in which rights abuses can occur. humans as a consequence of overcrowding; Inhuman and degrading treatment that is reported to the European Court of Human Rights for violation of article 3; practices of sexual assaults in prisons; lack of medical care, lack of educational services and, above all, lack of resources. Because it is essential that democratic states invest adequately in the prison system. That is why I join in congratulating the initiative and support report, above all, the vector aimed at reinforcing reintegration, because this has to be the orientation of custodial sentences, and therefore, especially, I support the paragraph that the report dedicates to alternative measures to deprivation of liberty: open regime measures.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this debate on prison systems and conditions allows me to raise a very particular issue, and I am grateful to the Catholic bishops of England and Wales for coming to me and meeting me on this issue. In England and Wales there are over 4 000 EU citizens in prisons, and while in the Brexit negotiations there is a desire to include the treatment of these prisoners in the negotiations and have a settlement on it, it is not yet clear what that will mean. The Catholic bishops tell me that they are very much involved in the pastoral care of these prisoners. The Home Secretary can deport EU citizens who commit offences but this is currently restricted by European law. Post-Brexit, EU citizens who have problems with the system in the UK after withdrawal are likely to fall under the provisions set out in the UK Borders Act of 2007, which contains far less restrictive grounds for deportation and requires deportation of foreign offenders sentenced to at least 12 months in prison. I think we need to understand that this is a very sensitive issue, and again I am grateful to the Church leaders for raising it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and say that it is a necessary report, I support it and I will vote for it. We need a change of attitude, it is an excess of pre-trial detention, it is a lack of responsibility of magistrates who, without having enough evidence, take citizens into pre-trial detention. This is proved, in fact, by the fact that many pre-trial detainees subsequently have no punishment and win at the ECHR and the national budgets are emptied. I'm sorry that some colleagues throw words and leave. The EPP colleague accuses Romania of not taking its detainees. It is a decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union, but why other countries, such as Great Britain, a recent example, host an evasionist from Romania, although Romania asks him in the country to judge him. There are two sides to it and, Commissioner, if that were the responsibility of the magistrates, we could come up with optimal solutions. And there is a need for integration programs in society after these people get out of prison, not, as a colleague said, that we help detainees. We help society to stop being attacked by these people who are not then integrated into society after they finish their sentence.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - The function of prisons is to educate criminals so that they can return to social life freed from criminal tendencies.Unfortunately, in many European Union countries, prisons have become real schools of crime.Many inmates who have been convicted of occasional offenses leave prisons to become professional criminals.On the other hand, criminals are sentenced by the courts to a sentence that deprives them of freedom but does not deprive them of their dignity as human beings.It has been shown that the Member States, by themselves, do not show the capacity to change this state of affairs.Only the creation, Commissioner, of a European prison model can positively change this state of affairs.This European prison model, the only European one, is also a requirement for European integration.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, prison conditions and prison overcrowding are critical issues in many of our Member States. There really are too many people in detention facilities who reoffend and turn to more serious crime after being released. Too many commit suicide. Too many mentally ill people are locked in facilities that are not appropriate for their condition and too many of our young turn to violent extremism upon their release. Often detention in prison is the starting point of a vicious circle of imprisonment and crime. This is why I welcome the report’s call for improved prison conditions and dissemination of good practices and alternative punishments, individual social care of prisoners and insistence on social reintegration. Decreasing crime and increasing social cohesion takes more than improving conditions in prisons. The overarching aim should be to have a penal, educational and social paradigm shift, to turn away from punishment and to insist on the social rehabilitation and reintegration of the convicted. It would be nice to study the case of Japan and how they succeeded.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, it is indeed clear that promiscuity in prisons offers the conditions for a form of contamination between prisoners, the misdeeds of which are not all of the same nature or of the same importance. There is a great risk of seeing prisoners convicted of minor offenses being drawn into greater delinquency, or even into radicalization. This is the reason why the countries of the European Union must favor alternative sentences to prison. There are many formulas, including community service. When I was mayor, I always responded favorably to judicial bodies that asked me to welcome these condemned to community service. Each time, I congratulated myself on the results and the involvement of my staff in their support. Unfortunately, in some cases there is no alternative to prison, so the reception conditions have to be created for the reintegration of prisoners. Professional training inside the prison is obviously a very essential element of this success.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, prisoners are finally being promoted to institutional interlocutors on the basis of sham fundamental rights. The needs and proposals of penitentiaries are being devalued in a discriminatory manner and the Member States' process on their penitentiary system is eroding. Prison renovation and modernization projects are inhumane, when Banks plunder citizens' property. It is humiliating to open penitentiary educational facilities when schools are closed in areas of strategic importance. It is absurd to suggest non-custodial sentences invoking the capacity of prisons. Epic and unthinkable ridiculous interfaith dialogue in prisons as a means of tackling radicalization. Finally, I emphasize the need to remove extremists and illegal immigrants from the general prison population, to separate detainees such as minors from adults, to have access to the necessary medical coverage equivalent to other citizens, and to complete the entire process. Prisons, of course, are not luxury hotels.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Jourová, the overcrowding of European prisons is one of the great unresolved issues of our continent. In recent years, the overcrowding of prisons has become a major concern, fortunately, also for the Council of Europe, which is committed to monitoring the standards of practice in European prisons. Statistics show that many countries still have very high overcrowding rates, despite policies to improve conditions. In carrying out institutional activities in Italy, I myself carried out monitoring activities on the health situation of prisons and I was able to verify that all the problems of the various institutions I visited were inexorably linked to overcrowding. In some institutions the situation is so serious that it ends up generating real health emergencies, compromising the dignity, as well as the health of prisoners and prison workers. Having facilities with a limited number of detainees ensures decent conditions of detention and encourages rehabilitation, reintegration into society. The deprivation of liberty cannot and must not constitute a deprivation of dignity. And this is the direction in which Europe must move.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - President! Dear colleagues! Many are in prison for a variety of reasons and situations. Unfortunately, there are those who are innocent, there are those who are said to be white-collar criminals for looting public funds. We meet few of these, and there are very many who have lived inhuman destinies throughout their lives, from an early age, and have become criminals in this context. I recently read a statement from a penitentiary who said I love my profession because I can help people in difficult situations get their lives back on track. This is what is a common task for everyone, and this is what prison would be doing. Paradoxically, as a criminal lawyer, I can say that there are a lot of people in prison who have experienced for the first time in their lives, exactly during criminal proceedings and in prison, what it means to be a person with human dignity because they are treated there for the first time in their lives. It is in the interest of society as a whole that once he is released, he does not commit another crime, because somewhere he has finally learned what it means to live a life worthy of man.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - President! There are many lessons to be learned from this debate today, and I think that both Mrs Jourová and the Commission's experts are very much considering the proposals that we have put forward here. I would like to point out another aspect that may have come up less in the debate - I will nevertheless vote on this report - namely, I would like to say a few thoughts, a few words about who are really in innocent prison, and these are children born in prison. . There are not a few of these, although no statistics are available, but according to newspaper reports, we often read that someone is imprisoned pregnant and that child is born in prison. This child, this is clearly the time that the mother has received, almost she herself will spend in prison, become a special institution, or, if appropriate, be left with the mother. I am definitely in favor of a Turkish spear to leave children with their mothers, whatever happens, and even for mothers, even house arrest may be an alternative. But most importantly, there is a need to create nuanced circumstances where people with similar problems are in a group rather than confused, such as a murderer with the perpetrator of a traffic accident. So, overall, this report is forward-looking, thank you very much to the rapporteurs, and in any case I suggest that we think a lot more about children, and not just newborns, but those who might otherwise be similarly concerned on this subject.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all, I wanted to thank our rapporteur, Joëlle Bergeron, for the work she carried out on this report. We are here today to stress the urgency of the worrying situation in European prisons. The example of France is the most emblematic of this alarming state of prisons in Europe: record prison overcrowding with more than 10,000 missing places, worrying and unworthy detention conditions, nearly 1,500 detainees considered to be radicalized, staff despised prison, with totally unworthy working conditions. And France is not an isolated case. (The President interrupts the speaker) In May 2016, I sent a letter and a questionnaire to all the ministers of justice of the Member States to get an overview of the situation of prisons in Europe. A third of the countries are in a state of prison overcrowding and all have difficulty in reintegrating their prisoners, most of which report a recidivism rate above 40%. Yes, prison policy is a national competence, but the challenges of the deterioration of the situation are the same for everyone. The most glaring examples are violence in prisons and the detention of increasingly difficult and dangerous prisoners, such as radicalized prisoners. We must find and promote common guidelines. It’s our responsibility. Prison must evolve, adapt to new forms of delinquency and criminality as well as to new profiles of prisoners. In this report, I recommend the establishment of differentiated detention regimes according to the dangerousness of the detainees. It is unacceptable today that prisons are not taken into account in national and European strategies to combat terrorism. Yet they are at the heart of the problem and are part of the solution. Terrorist attacks in Europe are multiplying, while prison, along with the internet, is the main vector of radicalization.We cannot be inactive.Another major aspect to be addressed without further delay is the issue of reintegration to prevent recurrence.These reintegration measures must absolutely be internalized and begin during detention.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, this is a very serious and important debate about very serious issues. I see two big problems here: one, which you have mentioned many times, is the lack of respect for the dignity of individuals, and this what we see by breaching human rights in European prisons. The second big issue was not debated here so frequently and this is the fact that we have many innocent people in European prisons. This is not only the case regarding people who are in pre-trial detention, where they have the right to the presumption of innocence. They have not been tried and they have the right to better conditions in European prisons.  When we debate this issue I am thinking about how we can help more because you have said many times, and I also said it at the beginning, that the EU has a quite weak competence here. I was exploring some legislative possibility to improve the situation of pre-trial detention, but we do not see enough space to do that, so we are focusing on three things: funding; training of professionals; and sharing, and helping to share, best practices.  On the question of funding, of course we see a lack of money here and when I discuss it with those responsible in the Member States – the experts – I sometimes hear varying information or suggestions. It is not politically popular to ask for money to improve the situation in prisons, because people will ask: why do you not give more funding to schools and hospitals? This is the reality, but this is not the answer. We have to look into it. I was addressed by 11 Ministers of Justice by letter, who asked the EU to help with funding and I replied with a very precise description of where and how EU funds can be used for improving the situation, and helping them to solve the most serious issues such as overcrowding and bad conditions. I see the possibility of using EU funds – the European Development Fund – for investments in prisons, for investments into technological or technical measures to introduce more alternative kinds of penalties. We see a lot of possibilities from the European Social Fund for better rehabilitation of inmates into normal life and for training practitioners working in prisons and in probation services. So there are possibilities, but we need to invest more political will in it.  My interest is also, as you have mentioned many times here, to have the European Arrest Warrant fully functioning. I am in continuous debate with the respective Member States where we have the problems on how to change the situation. So we are working, I think, exactly in the direction which many of you have suggested here. I have been in several prisons in European Member States. Everywhere, I saw the need to reorganise the service.  You mentioned several times that radicalisation is a problem here. Radicalisation is a very serious problem. We have seen the statistics which show that about 15% of radicalised people are radicalised in prisons, and so we see a clear need to work more on an individual basis and also on the reorganisation of working and structures in prisons to come up with effective solutions to this big problem.  We also see that more investments are necessary, and I have already spoken about financing. A change of approach is also necessary here and I see some very good examples. That is why sharing best practices is so important. Two weeks ago, I was in Austria, in the village of Gerasdorf, in a detention centre for young people, and I saw a very good example of how to work with young people who have the right to be given a second chance to get back to normal life. I saw a very good programme of requalification and I think that these are examples which should be followed in all the Member States. Again, political will and money are both necessary, so let us work in that direction. Thank you very much for these debates. Thank you for the report, Ms Bergeron, and let us continue working together on this issue.

name: Joëlle Bergeron
text: , rapporteur. - Mr. President, I do not have much to add. The debate has been very interesting and I see that most of us share the same outlook. I will take these few moments to thank my shadow rapporteurs. And this is not a formula, this report would not have been what it is if Eva Joly, Rachida Dati, Ms. Chinnici and others had not brought their enlightened skills to me. For the first three, they are former judges. They know what they are talking about, and they talk about it skillfully, intelligently and humanely. They shed some very enriching light on many points. This report fascinated me, and I am quite proud of its content, because I realized that the defense of human dignity and human rights could lead us to go beyond our political sensitivities and, above all, you. , yours. I believe it is also a real success to stand up for human beings with the same will. I will use Eva Joly's words: "Prison does not protect society, and of course that is its role". Above all, it is asked to protect the victims from their attackers and the rest of society. However, in the current state of affairs, the prison does not play that role. The mixture of prisoners, especially in remand centers, where, as many of you have recalled, innocent prisoners are mixed with prisoners who, for their part, will be sentenced because they have committed misdeeds, is very dangerous. This system criminalizes the innocent, but above all, it puts prison staff in great danger. There you are, I think this subject is extremely broad. There is obviously the problem of radicalization, but also the incarceration of psychiatric patients, who should be treated and that of minors, who should be educated and rehabilitated. These are huge problems, and we have only scratched the surface. It It would be necessary to take the subjects one by one and to plan for each ad hoc measures.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today, i.e. on Thursday 5 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- The report on prison systems and conditions proposes a number of steps to improve living conditions in prisons, as well as improving the process of reintegration of prisoners.The European Union aims to support the Member States in their efforts to improve prison conditions.By opening this topic, we can more effectively address, for example, the shortcomings of the reintegration process, but mainly to combat the phenomenon of radicalization.Too often, imprisonment is accompanied by living conditions that constitute inhuman or degrading treatment.Prison conditions are only one aspect of the overall issue of imprisonment.Affordable and high-quality training for prison staff that promotes solutions can also lead to a gradual improvement in prison conditions.In conclusion, it should be noted that we will not be able to solve this problem overnight, but nevertheless the opening of an honest debate symbolizes developments in the right direction.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - More than a third of Member States have recognized that prison overcrowding in the European Union is a persistent problem, and the situation in some Member States continues to deteriorate, severely impairing the quality of prison conditions and having severe effects on prisoners' health and well-being. the welfare of prison staff. Every member state should respect the prison rules arising from the instruments of international law and the standards of the Council of Europe, because deprivation of liberty does not mean deprivation of dignity! In addressing overcrowding, increasing prison capacity is not the only solution, but requires criminal justice systems that take into account the reintegration and rehabilitation of prisoners in order to protect both the prisoner and society and to reduce recidivism. In addition, prisoners need to be provided with access to educational and professional qualifications and work and training for the purpose of re-socialization, thus providing them with the opportunity to live without crime after the end of their sentence. I can say with certainty that programs for the reintegration of prisoners into society improve our societies and that all Member States should ensure that programs of this type are implemented in all prisons.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on eight motions for resolutions on the situation of people with albinism in Africa, in particular in Malawi (2017/2868 (RSP)).

name: Bodil Valero
text: Author. - Mr President! One in 20,000 people in the world has albinism and in Nigeria alone about 2 million of them live. Discrimination against people with albinism is a serious problem in sub-Saharan Africa, but also in the rest of the world. About 600 attacks were carried out on people with albinism in a total of 26 countries last year. In many cases, the reason has been the belief that their body parts have qualities that bring happiness and prosperity. A superstition that for us is completely absurd and that was thought could not live on in the 21st century. Although a number of countries are actually trying to stop these horrific attacks and trafficking in body parts, there is often a lack of adequate legislation to actually prosecute the perpetrators. Witness protection is also a necessary measure to make people dare to testify. It is imperative that the countries concerned take action to put an end to these killings and to this trade and to prosecute the criminals. But preventive work is at least as important. There is a need for awareness-raising efforts aimed at the general public that provide greater knowledge, but also information about albinism and why certain individuals are affected. This in combination with increased efforts to protect people with albinism. It can be about sheltered housing and it can be about increased police presence, but not least it is about working against the poverty and discrimination that this group suffers from more than the general population.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Author. Mayeso Isaac, that's the name of the last victim we know. An innocent 12-year-old boy kidnapped, sold and murdered, probably because of his hair or bones, out of superstition that this would have magical powers. That is what is currently happening. In the last 9 months, Malawi has been hit by another wave of atrocities against people with albinism. At least two have been murdered and seven others are reportedly discriminated against and prosecuted. As a colleague said, we know that this is just the tip of the iceberg. We have already seen reports of 600 people being discriminated against, persecuted and killed. One in 20,000 people in Africa is affected by albinism. So it's our goddamn duty to protect their human rights too. Just because they look different doesn't mean they should be killed. Colleagues, let us not adopt the attitude here in this European Parliament: "it is a long way off, it is only happening in Africa". No, we must make sure that this superstition ends in 2017. And we can. We must provide better education. We must ensure that criminal organizations that trade in human body parts because blonde hair is said to have magical powers are dealt with and punished. We must ensure that children with albinism are protected and that discrimination is eliminated. Colleagues, let's make sure that the human rights of everyone on this planet, regardless of skin color, are protected.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the figures for murders, assaults and disappearances of albino people in Malawi, Tanzania or Burundi are shocking: in the last two years, at least twenty people have been murdered and more than one hundred and fifteen have been victims of some type of aggression. , not counting those who are missing. The Government of Malawi must take political and judicial measures to stop these attacks. Likewise, the European Union and the United States, which are the main donors to this country, have to demand respect for human rights in the region and especially the protection of this group at risk. But we cannot simply ask for respect for human rights in an abstract way. I think it is also essential to question an economic model of neocolonial resource plundering that kills hunger, deforests, generates droughts and floods, reduces crops and ruins crops. Ladies and gentlemen, violence against albino people is not only the product of superstition and witchcraft, but it is also a problem called poverty and hopelessness. We will have to tackle both.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, albinos in Africa face widespread discrimination and persecution. Last year alone, 172 albinos were murdered and almost 300 were attacked in hunts for their body parts. In Malawi, a new wave of killings and persecution has started in the current year, while the local justice system has failed to protect this vulnerable minority from criminal gangs. We call on the Malawian authorities to their utmost to protect albino citizens, who clearly deserve strong state guarantees for safety, dignity and equality. I call on the Malawian Government to follow the positive examples of Tanzania and Mozambique, where action programmes have been started to promote public awareness and education and to protect co-citizens.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. - Mr President, I will speak Swedish now. Colleagues and Commissioner Jourová! I want to give my voice to an urgent matter like this, for people with albinism in Malawi and in other African states. What is the current situation? Well, people with albinism are killed and discriminated against on a daily basis. Not even the dead are allowed to be at peace from these people who use their body parts. These people's lives are at risk wherever they go. Women and children are even more vulnerable. Children are cut and their body parts sold. But how can we then face this horrific situation? I call for better legislation and better implementation of existing laws and action plans. I ask for better resources and training for the police. The EU institutions cannot turn a blind eye to this. We need a monitoring mechanism that follows this development. It's time to act and react. I would also like to point out that structural discrimination must also be met with greater knowledge and a changed approach. We can not let people still die because of their skin color in 2017. So Malawi and other African states must protect all their people who are there. And our job is to make sure that happens.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, the plight of albino people in Malawi is a true tragedy. I still remember debating this same issue in relation to Tanzania almost a decade ago. The apparent killing of innocent albinos – or persons with albinism – and, tragically, mainly of children, for their body parts is still happening in many African states as well as Malawi, where there has been a recent spate and rise in the number of killings to more than 20. Other states reportedly affected include Burundi, Mozambique, Kenya, Nigeria and Zambia. Already, this vulnerable community is at risk of the medical consequences of albinism in the tropics, including a high risk of fatal skin cancer, but they are also now being murdered – almost unbelievably – to satisfy demand for traditional medicine that is more akin to medieval sorcery. The EU should not hesitate to campaign on the issue. I welcome the reforms of the penal code in Malawi. I also welcome the recent adoption of the regional action plan for 2017-2021 jointly by the African Union and the United Nations. This is a positive and concrete signal of commitment by African leaders to ending all discrimination against persons with albinism and to prosecuting all crimes and atrocities against this vulnerable group of people.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, Malawi, along with other African countries, is facing an awful violation of human rights towards people with albinism, due to erroneous superstitions and beliefs about this rare genetic condition. Constantly targeted by gangs and individuals driven by ignorance and myths about the magical powers of their body parts, people with albinism are facing pretty much all kinds of human abuses, from mutilation, abduction, killings, rapes, to social discrimination and exclusion from access to basic public services. Governments of these countries are facing an enormous struggle in order to stop these heinous crimes and to prosecute their authors. In this joint resolution, we call for the EU and its Member States to keep engaging with the countries affected, in order to effectively support their efforts to formulate policies addressing the special needs and rights of persons with albinism, by providing the necessary financial and technical assistance. Among others, I think that the creation of specific local task forces within the police with the specific aim of preventing and investigating these crimes could be a useful tool.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this subject has been a taboo for many years, during which time few MEPs have been interested in it, including myself. This is why we wanted to present a document for the signature of our group, to underline the fact that for some time we have denounced this problem, which was evidently considered delicate, taboo, because no one has ever seriously dealt with it. Obviously, not the African governments that were directly affected because 27 sub-Saharan African states are affected by this problem. Of course, in some of these, the problem is greater. We talk about Malawi. President Mutharika intervened to denounce the fact, even if there are no concrete measures to prosecute the traffickers of body parts and even the bodies of the dead. It is an unclean trade, it is a taboo, a very serious thing, one of the most ignoble forms of truly deleterious persecution. Taboo subject, parallel to which during this day of discussion on human rights in Africa, Parliament should have had the courage to also touch on another taboo subject, which we are few to raise in this House, namely that of anti-white racism. But in reality we are talking about albinos and therefore in a certain sense, this too is anti-white racism: it is about weak subjects, subjects that must be protected, subjects against whom concrete action is needed. And then Europe should make its voice heard much more strongly to the UN, but also to the African Union, which has so many reasons to listen to Europe's voice. The African Union must concretely engage with individual governments and strike where there is cover against these trafficking which shame the whole world.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! As you can see, stigmatization has been a recurring theme for years. We also discussed the stigma and violation of the fundamental rights of people with albinism in Africa in this Chamber in July last year. It is regrettable that there is no progress in improving the legal protection and action for victims, and in providing them with adequate appeal and rehabilitation mechanisms. People with albinism living in Malawi - but also in Tanzania and Mozambique - fear that they will be abducted by gangs, killed or mutilated, and this limits their sense of security, freedom of movement and of course - perhaps most importantly - access to education and health care. In the context of the regional action plan mentioned by colleague Tunne Kelam, the African Human Rights Commission adopted such a plan in June this year, but it is important that countries affected by this cruel practice develop specific strategies focusing on education and awareness-raising activities on the topic of albinism. I also believe that local authorities and civil society organizations in particular must play a key role in defending this group of people.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that of albinos is an unknown drama which has caused hundreds of victims for years. Yet theirs is a hereditary genetic condition which, on the contrary, should also be adequately treated by the health facilities of the country. Of course, we cannot ignore the progress made by some countries, primarily Tanzania, in their effort to include, even politically, people suffering from albinism. Something is moving, also thanks to the awareness-raising activity of the European Union and the Regional Action Plan of the African Union and the United Nations, which is a positive but also concrete sign of commitment on the part of African leaders. Remember that the primary responsibility of a state is to protect its citizens, including vulnerable groups. We therefore call on the government of Malawi to guarantee effective protection for people with albinism, in order to defend their right to life and personal safety. It is unacceptable that these people are not only subject to extreme violence, but also victims of persecution and social exclusion. We also need a cultural action, Mr. President, that puts an end to the stigmatization of these people, starting with schools, an action aimed at eradicating ancient and sedimented practices, which today, in 2017, must no longer find space in any concept of modernity or tradition. Albinos will not be forgotten or abandoned to their fate.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I will join in my speech here on what my predecessors have said.It is good that we are adopting a resolution today in which we clearly condemn the practices against this group of people in Africa.In my opinion, it is very right that in the resolutions we describe in detail what is happening to albinos in Africa, and in this case in Malawi in particular.On the other hand, I must say that this resolution is very descriptive and that it would be good for the Commission, as the EU's executive body, in its specific diplomacy to give more attention to how to put pressure on African states and in this case Malawi to give clear protection to albinos.The report makes it clear what horrors are happening to this group of people.It is incomprehensible that such things can happen at the beginning of the 21st century.And it is our moral duty to do our utmost to protect these people.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! The situation for albinos in Africa is dark and frightening, and it looks more like medieval practice than a modern problem. Unfortunately, as a result of the belief that the body parts of albinos have extraordinary power, the price for them reaches $ 75,000 on the black market, which for an average Tanzanian means 150 years of work. Despite the fact that killing an albino carries the death penalty, the amount of this amount, as well as the very low percentage of detentions, mean that murder or mutilation of people suffering from vitiligo is frequent. Therefore, one should focus primarily on educational activities to convince the public that the magical power of albino amulets is a superstition that does not translate into reality. In addition, measures should also be taken to improve the lives of albinos, ensuring their access to education and health care, as well as psychological support. I would also like to point out that the popular locking of albinos in centers, unfortunately, currently only gives an apparent sense of security.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, more than a year ago we adopted a resolution here on the human rights violations of people with albinism in Africa, namely in Malawi. After this time we have seen an alarming resurgence of murders and attacks against albinos in East Africa, Malawi, Tanzania, South Africa or Mozambique. Albinos, including many children, continue to pay a terrible price for their condition. In addition to being rejected by their own families, they are victims of groups of criminals and traffickers, often protected by the police, who live by harvesting parts of their bodies to feed the macabre and very lucrative business of magic potions associated with the belief that they have magical powers. . This House cannot fail to strongly condemn violence and discrimination against people with albinism, urging the authorities of these countries to end the impunity of those responsible and to support all campaigns that, through actions to raise awareness of the causes of this congenital disorder, to combat discrimination, prejudice and superstition. We cannot tolerate the continuation of this true genetic apartheid.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, expelled from communities and tortured, but also mutilated and killed and without certain penalties for the persecutors: this is the situation of people suffering from albinism who live in many countries of sub-Saharan Africa, but also in the Pacific and India. The situation is more serious in the state of Malawi, where every year many people with albinism are killed and maimed and their body parts are sold for use in ritual practices. Amnesty International, in its report "We are not animals to be hunted or sold", argues that since 2014 the cases of kidnapping and murder have increased, forcing albinos to live constantly in terror. The European Union and the international community must take all possible actions to guarantee respect for their rights and the dignity of human beings for people with albinism. The governments of the countries where these crimes are perpetrated, such as Malawi, must be induced in every way to offer effective protection to people with albinism, to protect their right to life and personal safety.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I support the resolution, which I have co-signed. People with albinism are subject to real persecution. These are at least 20,000 of our fellow human beings. Murders, kidnappings, mutilations, humiliating acts are what are happening not only in Malawi but in several African countries. Women who give birth to children with albinism abandon them. All this happens because there is superstition, there is magic and it is believed that parts of the body parts of alphas can be used to make medicine. There are "hunters" of people with albinism. You realize, then, that this situation must end. Human trafficking must be criminalized and action taken in Tanzania, Mozambique, Nigeria and Kenya must be encouraged and countries must take steps to protect people suffering from albinism.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
