text: – Mr President, I, too, am deeply concerned and appalled by the situation of albino people in Malawi, Tanzania and other African countries. The ongoing stigmatisation, attacks, murder and selling of body parts, to which persons with albinism fall victim, are truly horrifying. Persons with albinism are marginalised, isolated and subjected to extreme violence and violations of their fundamental human rights. I urgently call on the governments of the affected countries to bring the perpetrators to justice, and to end the impunity which they currently seem to enjoy. It is necessary that health care, education and employment opportunities are made more accessible to albino people and that victims are supported. The EU must stand strong and not allow these abuses of human rights to continue. Lastly, I would like to congratulate my fellow MEPs for their work, and their speeches here today, to try and help bring these despicable practices to an end.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, indeed, people with albinism often go through hell because society is not sufficiently informed. This is particularly the case in Malawi and in a number of African countries. It is therefore the responsibility of States to demonstrate education in relation to this, but also to take measures to protect these populations weakened by beliefs out of our time. The victims, especially women, who are often victims of rape, must be cared for and protected, as superstitious practices claim that sex with a woman with albinism is a cure for AIDS. Realize! States must also pay particular attention to child victims of this situation because they often and frequently become painkillers in schools. The European Union can and must help the states concerned to inform and educate the populations on this issue. It is an absolute necessity, because it is the basis of the lasting solution. This does not exclude the responsibility of states to protect their populations.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, this case is as disgusting as the hundreds of others that are happening.It was only when I read this resolution that I understood that I am not reading a scene from ancient centuries, but that this is the current situation in some African countries.I think we need to think about how we can fight superstitions, because through education - that is one of the ways on offer - it will be a very long time.Of course, it is necessary to educate people in this area, but in my opinion, these people need protection as soon as possible.Draconian punishments need to be laid down, the protection of the governments of these African countries concerned needs to be unequivocally increased, because that is probably the only way to combat this way of thinking today, with these superstitions that may have a long history but into the 21st century.does not really fit.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to express my appreciation for this opportunity to speak on a significant human rights issue. In recent years, we have registered a worrying increase in human rights abuses against people with albinism in Malawi and other sub-Saharan African countries. These criminal and discriminatory incidents involve violent attacks, abductions, human trafficking and killings. When the subject was last discussed in this House, honourable Members drew attention to a number of crucial actions which needed to be pursued. These actions remain highly relevant today. That is why the EU has been engaging with the concerned countries, urging protection and policing in communities where attacks against albinos are rife, while encouraging the authorities to bring the perpetrators of these crimes to justice. This requires, inter alia, increased cooperation across borders because the problem often has a regional dimension. At the same time, honourable Members, we have also supported your recognition of the need to tackle the roots of social stigma against people with albinism, as well as encouraging acknowledgement of their specific needs, be they medical, psychological, educational or social. This challenge requires a longer-term commitment, implying close cooperation with all the stakeholders, including civil society, which has a role to play in confronting social beliefs deeply entrenched in superstition. On a more positive note, the international community is also increasingly mobilising against this situation. On 13 June, we marked International Albinism Awareness Day. That and the recent appointment of the first ever United Nations independent expert on the enjoyment of human rights by persons with albinism are important steps towards increasing awareness of this issue. Moreover, the governments concerned are demonstrating increasing recognition of the scale of this problem, which is a positive initial step. We stand ready for further engagement with our partners, and, through our delegations, the EU will continue supporting local civil-society efforts. Our aim is that persons with albinism will be fully able to live in dignity, free from violence and discrimination.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place today.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Too often in many African countries, albinos suffer physical and sexual violence, harassment, persecution, discrimination and in some cases even killed.Furthermore, women and children suffering from albinism are particularly vulnerable to social exclusion, bullying and often live in terror of being attacked.The 5 Star Movement has always stood up to combat violations of human rights and to protect minorities from inhumane acts, such as those who are forced to suffer from albinos in Africa.The institutions of Malawi must be urged to address and combat the harmful superstitions that lead to discrimination against albinos, through information campaigns, also collaborating with international partners.The EU must play a key role in supporting these actions, monitoring and supporting African states, to end the barbarity that albinos are forced to endure.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Albinism is an inherited genetic disorder, but it is misunderstood in Malawi and some other countries. As a result, people are killed and harmed in order to bring strength and success. Women with albinism disorder are raped because it is believed that having sex with them can cure HIV and AIDS. Murders, mutilation, discrimination, harassment and stigmatization have forced hundreds of people with albinism displacement to move to temporary shelters in areas, reducing their access to basic services such as health care and education, employment and participation in society. In this context, it is essential that the Malawian Government take active steps to protect those with a genetic disorder of albinism, to prevent violence against them, and to provide all necessary medical and psychological assistance. Violence against people with albinism is cross-border, so I believe it is necessary to strengthen regional cooperation in this area, promote educational programs that dispel prevailing myths and help a vulnerable group to socialize and become equal members of society.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the discussion of five motions for resolutions on the cases of Tatar leaders Akhtem Chiygoz and Ilmi Umerov and journalist Mykola Semena in Crimea (2017/2869 (RSP)).

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Thank you for supporting this resolution. It is very important. The United Nations Human Rights Office just adopted a report in September reporting serious human rights violations on the occupied territory of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea and the city of Sevastopol. The United Nations Human Rights Office explains how Crimean Tatars, journalists, bloggers and anyone who criticizes the Crimean occupation or Putin's policies in Crimea can be arrested and imprisoned. There are reports of people disappearing, people being terrorized by the secret service and psychiatric and torture in detention. Most importantly, in this resolution that we are adopting today, that those who disappear in Putin's camps and prisons are given names, that those people appear. In addition, I find the demand very important that our Foreign Service, our Embassy and also the Council of Europe and the United Nations put more pressure on so that international delegations can monitor the situation in Crimea. It cannot be that - as under Stalin - people from the Crimea in the camps - today not Stalin, but Putin - disappear and we cannot do anything in this situation, although Russia in principle belongs to the Council of Europe. We should support the call by the Ukrainians that the General Assembly of the United Nations specifically deal with these problems following the report I mentioned at the beginning. Otherwise we have to ensure that the sanctions that have been imposed because of the occupation of Crimea are upheld, that we, like the United Nations, continue to maintain that Crimea is occupied territory. We should punish the entrepreneurs with the bridge von Kerch or in the energy sector break these sanctions.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Mr President, the non-recognition of Crimea’s occupation is not just a political declaration, it is an obligation to act. I call on the European External Service: each and every case of repressed Crimean dissidents must be followed by our action, I mean by asset-freezing and a travel ban against those who are responsible. I have got a note from independent Russian analysts who say that over 130 European Union companies still enjoy trading with Crimea. An absolute majority of them have a Cypriot legal registration. This scandalous and shocking political business scheme must be stopped immediately and investigated thoroughly. The Commission must act and take all legal measures against these sanctions-violators.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, dissent is not a crime. As a human rights defender, a feminist and coming from a minority myself, I must speak out against the dire situation in occupied Crimea. Today we highlight the cases of two Crimean Tatar leaders and one journalist. But the problem is much, much broader. There is a disturbing pattern of repression of independent voices. So often across the world minority groups are in vulnerable situations and we must secure their rights.  We demand that the de facto Russian authorities reverse their convictions. They must end the persecution and harassment of Crimean Tatars, human rights defenders, journalists, lawyers, and all other target groups. And as I said before, we must secure their rights.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Author. - Mister President! I am very happy that today we again have broad consensus among five groups on this matter and that we are making it clear that together we continue to regard the occupation of Crimea as an illegal act that violates international law and that we are not just looking at territories in the abstract but very specifically care about people who suffer from this occupation. It is correct that we name the Tatar leaders here: Ahtem Çiygoz, İlmi Ümerov and the journalist Mykola Semena. They - and also their relatives and Russia, all of them - should know that these people have not been forgotten. That is why we have included the other political prisoners who were arrested and sentenced in Crimea by the Russian authorities in the list of those mentioned here. We demand their immediate release, because they are in fact political prisoners and have committed nothing other than campaigning for the independence of their homeland and membership of Crimea. We should continue to call these brave people by name and give them political and moral support. I think that's our job here.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: author. – Mr President, three years after the illegal annexation of Crimea, Russia is tightening its grip on the community of the peninsula by means of terror, massive violations of human, citizens’ and political rights, and by means of killings, abductions, illegal detentions and deprivation of basic rights. This policy is affecting, in particular, the indigenous community of Crimean Tatars. Their political representation, the Mejlis, was banned and two prominent Mejlis leaders, Mr Ilmi Umerov and Mr Akhtem Chiygoz, were given lengthy prison sentences, as was Mr Mykola Semena, a journalist linked to Radio Free Europe. In our resolution we provide a long list of prisoners – political prisoners, prisoners of conscience – who are to be remembered. We also know the names of perpetrators of massive human rights violations, including judges sentencing, in the name of illegal Russian courts, the patriots of the Ukraine, of the Tatar community. We need to broaden the group of people who are subject to our individual sanctions, to take restrictive measures against these people.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we are going to vote today on a resolution on the two Crimean Tatar leaders Akhtem Chiygoz and Ilmi Umerov, and the journalist Mykola Semena, who have been sentenced to prison for simply expressing their views. We demand their immediate release. But our debate is more general. We are speaking here about ongoing grave abuses by the Russian Federation of human rights in the illegally annexed Crimea region of Ukraine. The recently published UN Human Rights Council report about the human rights situation in Crimea states that imprisonments, arrests, tortures and abductions were amongst the actions targeted against people opposing the Russian annexation of Crimea. These inhuman and shameful practices demonstrate once again that Russia continuously violates international law and is a threat to European security. I therefore welcome the June prolongation of sanctions against Russia concerning its annexation of Crimea. The sanctions should be maintained and extended until the human rights of the people of Crimea are fully protected and Crimea is returned to Ukraine.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, ever since the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by Russia, this Parliament has been – and must remain – in the forefront of international protest against Putin’s expansionism. As we insist on restoring the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine, we must see beyond the legal and military consequences and must keep reminding Europe and the world of the human suffering and injustice the local population must endure, particularly the most daring, who challenge and fight the illegal occupation. This motion calls for our joint solidarity with the people of Crimea, especially of the local Tatar community whose members and leaders are Moscow’s main targets in repressing and avenging opposition, similarly to representatives of the free press. The convictions and detentions of Tatar leaders – who as Mejlis leaders are actually our colleagues – Ilmi Umerov and Akhtem Chiygoz, as well as the journalist Mykola Semena, must be reversed, their freedom and human rights restored.  However, their cases represent only the tip of the iceberg as far as Putin’s reckless repression is concerned, marked by violence, torture, illegal detention and transfer of detainees to Russia. This motion recalls the names of many other Crimean Tatar and other victims and as MEPs, we must remain vigilant and active in updating this dire list and highlighting every single case of human rights abuse. Also the EU needs to further empower and supply the EEAS, and support the UN, the OSCE and the civilians in their monitoring and humanitarian efforts.  Indeed, Putin behaves in Crimea like the worst kind of occupation force, following the most appalling inhuman Stalinist patterns, ignoring all norms of international law of human rights and of decency. I believe Crimea is the testing ground, as far as Europe’s tolerance and democratic determination is concerned. Let the Crimean Tatars’ fate be a reminder of this to all, in or out of the EU, who still nourish illusions about Moscow’s intentions, and who tend to regard the illegal annexation as a kind of fait accompli.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Russia’s illegal occupation and annexation of Crimea continues, and so must the EU’s resolve to protest about its action. Sadly, the situation is not getting any better. There are now new allegations of human rights violations in Crimea detailed in the UN Human Rights Agency’s report. It is also the case that the Crimean minority group, the Tatars, continue to be persecuted, which echoes the treatment of their grandparents under Stalin. The imprisonment of prominent Tatar dissidents, Akhtem Chiygoz, Ilmi Umerov and the journalist Mykola Semena, as well as the fact that the Tatars’ Parliament, the Majlis, has been closed, is deeply alarming. My group, the ECR, will continue to oppose Russia’s actions via EU sanctions and international pressure. The indigenous Turkic-speaking population must be allowed to live peacefully in their homeland of Crimea, and any efforts by the Russian Government to force them to leave the peninsula through policies of persecution or withdrawal of their democratic rights is totally unacceptable.

name: Urmas Paet
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the situation in Crimea tends sometimes to be overshadowed by other developments, but we cannot let this happen. According to the latest UN report, the human rights situation in Crimea has significantly deteriorated under Russian occupation. There are arbitrary arrests and detentions, enforced disappearances, ill-treatment and torture. Also, the imposition of Russian citizenship has affected tens of thousands of people. Persons holding a residence permit and no Russian Federation citizenship in Crimea cannot own agricultural land, vote or be elected, register a religious community, apply to hold a public meeting, hold positions in the public administration, and so on.  The Russian Government has an obligation, as an occupying power, to uphold human rights for all and effectively investigate alleged torture, abductions and killings. But of course, the only fundamental solution lies in Russia ending the occupation of Crimea and returning it to Ukraine.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: for the GUE / NGL Group.- Mr President, of course, no human rights violations can be tolerated.It is certainly a good thing that we are trying to deal with each individual case, but I am afraid we will not forget, for the sake of individuality, the violation of rights and the suffering of large groups of people.Just look at Ukraine, where there has been a protracted conflict for three years, affecting millions of people.It includes killing, torturing and torturing people, as well as eliminating uncomfortable journalists.According to a report by the Office of the UN High Commissioner this summer, which colleagues also quoted here, "There is a systematic violation of the right to a fair trial in conflict-related cases." We regularly denounce the situation in Crimea in plenary.In my opinion, however, we finally need to stop the double standard policy.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Crimea is a sweet bite for Russia, which has been in it for a long time.This peninsula has always been of great strategic importance to Russia.Russian aggression began in the 19th century.in the middle of the twentieth century.At the beginning of the 19th century, and after World War II, Stalin deported all Crimean Tatars because they allegedly collaborated with the Nazis.And now the 21st century.Russia has annexed Crimea again.This situation is most horrible for the Crimean Tatars, of whom there are few left in the Crimea, but who are the ancestors and hosts of this land.The history of the Crimean Tatars is much like the history of my nation, but they have experienced an incomparably more brutal long-term deportation.We must step up our efforts to help Ukraine recover the peninsula and, at the same time, ensure peace and a future for the Crimean Tatars as well.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Malawi, Maldives, Crimea, what crucial issues for Europeans that we are supposed to defend here! But four days ago in Marseilles, an Islamist slaughtered two innocent young girls, who have joined the long list of hundreds of victims of a religious war that goes by his name. Yet it stands within our walls, where it is led by enemies who have nothing to do with it, but who take advantage of your laxity and blindness to commit their crimes. This morning, we are therefore witnessing an anti-Putin indictment, on the pretext of the fate of people who have been regularly sentenced for disturbing public order, inciting subversion, undemocratic conduct or even, irony of the calendar, if one think of what happened last Sunday in Catalonia, for attempts to prevent, by violence, the holding of the referendum on the autonomy of Crimea. Well-ordered charity begins with oneself. So let’s deal with democracy within the Union and only after that can you teach the whole world a lesson.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President! I do not understand anything: yesterday I heard Mr Timmermans say that the most important thing is the rule of law, and today you want to introduce a totalitarian regime in Russia so that Mr Putin can change the judgments of independent courts at your request. You want totalitarianism! You know nothing about Crimea and Russia. I was in Crimea, there were 70% Russians all the time, 10% Ukrainians, 10% Tatars and 10% Russian-speaking Ukrainians. These were the people who ruled Crimea, because in order to be in power you had to be Ukrainian. Now the same people are Russians and the same people rule in Crimea and treat Tatars the same way. I am quoting Mr. Zair Smeldaliev, a Tatar activist who was accused of separatism during the Ukrainian rule, because he said that one day Crimea would be Tatar. And he says: “Now the same people from the Ukrainian security services who have threatened me and accused me of separatism are wearing Russian uniforms. Look who has become a separatist! " It is further from Crimea to Moscow than to Kiev, and that is the only thing that has changed from the point of view of the Crimean Tatars.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the alarming reports about the abuse of human rights in Crimea should not come as a surprise to anyone. Yet again, we observe how the Kremlin uses the judicial system as a tool to silence fair criticism and discontent among the people. Any state established upon the rule of law must ensure the protection of minorities and freedom of speech. On these most fundamental human rights, the Russian Federation is falling short. As representatives of the EU, we must condemn the unjust sentencing and demand the immediate release of Crimean Tatar leaders, Akhtem Chiygoz and Ilmi Umerov. The charges against journalist Mykola Semena should be dropped. Moreover, the EU must condemn the persecution and unfair policies against Crimean Tatars and continue to defend the European security order as we have known it since World War II.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: - Crimea has now been burdened by the Russian occupation for more than three years, with human rights violations being the order of the day.There is talk of torture and arbitrary arrests.The situation of the Crimean Tatars is the most dire.The Umerov, Chiygoz and Semena case, which we are discussing here, is exemplary.They are now paying a heavy price for criticizing the illegal annexation.After a shady trial, all three were sentenced to a disproportionately long prison term.As the EU, it is our duty to stand up for journalists and human rights activists, including beyond our borders.Crimea should not be forgotten.The situation of the inhabitants of the illegally annexed area must remain on the international agenda.That is why I also argue that the EU should continue to hold Russia accountable for this and stand up for the release of these three people.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: - Dear Commissioner, Crimea is a territory occupied by Russia with all the tragic consequences the occupation entails. This is clear to all of us - with the exception of Mr Korwin-Mikke. Arrests, persecutions and political repressions are the daily life of the Tatar people, who persistently try to defend the values ​​that are said to be fundamental to the European Union: human rights and respect for minorities. We call on the Russian Federation to release Tatar and Ukrainian political prisoners, whose only fault is persistent resistance to lawlessness. Because Russia is there illegally, and the Union should uphold the inviolability of borders. The accusations and sentences for the leaders of the Crimean Tatars Achtem Chijgoz, Ilmi Umerov and the journalist Mykola Semena are an important, but only a small part of the truth about the consequences of the Russian occupation of Crimea. I had the opportunity to hear many similar stories personally. The same methods and the same repressions were used by the Russians against Poles, Balts, Hungarians and the Czechs in the not-so-distant past. We still remember it. Only a firm reaction from the West and constant economic pressure can end this tragic situation of the Tatars in the Crimea.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the situation in eastern Ukraine remains volatile, uncertain and dangerous. The lack of political will to fully implement the Minsk agreements turns the conflict into a frozen one and practically intensifies the tendencies for division. Alas, in conditions of danger of military aggravation, human rights are always systematically violated. This is also the case in eastern Ukraine, where the rights of minorities are being systematically trampled upon and discriminatory actions against the Tatar population are becoming a severe reality. Commissioner, all countries in power must abide by international laws and norms and guarantee the fundamental human rights and freedoms of all citizens, regardless of their ethnic origin, gender or religion. Crimean Tatars are an integral part of the population of Crimea and their cultural and historical values ​​must be respected.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, today we are discussing the consequences of Russia's occupation of part of Ukraine.Russia occupies Crimea and Sevastopol against all rules of international law.We will never recognize the annexation of these territories to Russia, and these territories remain the territory of Ukraine for us.Being on the side of the law is an obvious crime for the Kremlin regime.The victims of human will have specific names contained in our resolution, such as Oleg Sencov, Ilmi Umerov or Roman Sušenko and many others.Not only the victims, but also the Russian will has specific names.The perpetrators of these crimes need to be identified and punished.At the moment, the EU can add them to its sanctions lists.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!Rebecca Harms said beautifully that victims cannot remain nameless, that is the best we can do for them right away.Persecuted nations cannot remain nameless either.The history of the Crimean Tatars, the history of Crimea in the 20th century is a heroic history, that is, resistance to the Bolshevik revolution (remember that the counter-revolution ended its heroic resistance in Crimea and the Tatars took part in it), it constituted a state recognized by the League of Nations, a stateThe Crimean Tatars are a terrible, wild deportation by Stalin during the war and a heroic return to their lands.In fact, the fate of the Crimean Tatars is a test, always a test of what is happening in Crimea.We cannot treat them only as a special case, as a community among which there are victims, but as an entity that has the right to say about the future of our land.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, Chuir sé déistin orainn go léir nuair a d’ionsaigh na Rúisigh an Chrimé trí bliana ó shin; faraor, níl aon fhonn abhaile orthu. Chuige sin, tá siad ag teacht anuas go trom ar mhuintir na Crimé, go háirithe na daoine atá ag caint amach ina gcoinne. Tá trí shampla de sin againn ar maidin: an bheirt cheannaire Tatar agus an t-iriseoir Semena. Dá bhrí sin, is cóir dúinn brú a chur ar na Rúisigh an bheirt cheannaire a ligint saor agus dul ar ais go dtína gclann agus na coireanna atá curtha i leith Semena, deireadh a chur leo.  Freisin, is ceart dúinn leanúint ar aghaidh leis an mbrú ginearálta, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le smachtbhannaí i gcoinne na Rúise go dtí go dtugann siad na cearta daonna do mhuintir na Crimé agus go dtéann siad ar ais abhaile.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the title of our resolution includes the names of three Crimean Tatars: Chiygoz, Umerov, Semena. According to reports, including the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner, we know that there are many more who are being persecuted, arrested, tortured, abducted or forced into exile for criticizing the Russian occupation of Crimea. The European Parliament must not remain silent on this situation. During the occupation, media freedom was severely suppressed, it essentially ceased to exist and today only pro-Russian news is available. We have reports that the people of Crimea are being forced to cooperate with Russian security forces under threats. We remember this very well from the time of totalitarianism in our country until 1989. However, there are still people in the Crimea who have not given up and are defending human rights. They must also be supported by our resolution and the call for the establishment of an international monitoring mission to the Crimea within the United Nations to report on the situation.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I welcome the fact that we are defending the leaders of the Crimean Tatars with this resolution.The names Achtem Chijgoz and Ilmi Umerov do not remain unknown to us.Just like journalist Mykola Semena.However, this resolution has a much deeper meaning than just rejecting unjust judgments.This resolution again evokes our memory.It recalls our obligation to repay the debt to those Crimean Tatars who in 1968 opposed the occupation of my country - Czechoslovakia - by the Soviet army.He recalls how tragically history can repeat itself - it was the Crimean Tatars who had once been subjected to genocide.I am thinking of their forced eviction from the Crimea in 1944. However, this resolution has another general meaning.It proves that the European Parliament is not evading and still calls things by their real names: the occupation of Crimea is a violation of international law.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is important that we keep on speaking out on the human rights violations that are happening on our doorstep in Ukraine and occupied Crimea. This resolution makes a clear call for the release of imprisoned Tatar leaders and activists. But we should not forget Ukrainian political prisoners in Russia, who have been languishing in prisons for years now. In particular, I have followed the case of the talented filmmaker Oleg Sentsov, who is in prison in Siberia, convicted on trumped-up charges. We must send a message out from this House that we will not be quiet and we will not forget these people who have been locked away. The EU must continue to put more and more pressure on the Russian Government to end its human rights violations and let these people go.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in the last weeks of last September, Ilmi Umerov, a prominent critic of the Russian occupation and leader of the Tatar people of Crimea, the Ukrainian journalist Mycola Semena and the leader of the Mejlis, Akhtem Chiygoz, were sentenced to prison terms. prison accused of threatening the territorial integrity of the Russian Federation. The condemnations of these three prominent critics of the Russian annexation of Crimea constitute the most recent episode of usurpation of fundamental rights and freedoms in the Ukrainian peninsula and the instrumentalization of the judicial system as a political tool for the repression of those who oppose Russian occupation and annexation. This is not the first time that we have condemned, in this House, Russia's systematic recourse to persecution, torture, arbitrary arrests and extrajudicial executions to silence dissenting voices and reduce the Crimean Tatar population to submission. These latest arrests also represent yet another serious violation of the right to freedom of expression, security and a fair trial guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights, to which the Russian Federation is a signatory, and for this reason we call for the removal of the charges and the release Akhtem Chiygoz, Ilmi Umerov and Mycola Semena.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, of course I completely agree with the text of that resolution, because there is no doubt that the judgments in this case are illegitimate, they are unfair, they are a violation of human rights. The occupation of Crimea is generally a violation of international law, which is quite clear, and Russia cannot, in my view, use its judiciary to legitimize these steps. Russia has become part of an enforceable range of international rights and those guaranteed by the Council of Europe system. And I think either the rights apply or it's a menu where only a certain part applies. We should try to help the Council of Europe to exercise part of its enforceable jurisdiction over Russia by seizing shares in Russian companies. We need to express our support for the Council of Europe, because it has this system in place. We can only continue to insist on that sanctions list. This is our expression of solidarity for our bad conscience, as the 1994 Budapest Memorandum was unilaterally violated.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Union and the international community do not recognise the illegal annexation of Crimea and continue to condemn the violation of international law, as well as the oppressive acts that represent a clear infringement of the human, civil, political and cultural rights of Crimean Tatars and other Crimean freedom fighters. Russia, as the occupying power of Crimea, has to respect international law. At the same time, I call on the Commission to look thoroughly at and to address the situation in Ukraine, where recently the Ukrainian authorities took measures against the rights of national minorities in Ukraine. This is a terrible situation. While all of us here are fighting for the rights of Ukrainians in Crimea, Ukraine is taking measures against the national minorities in Ukraine, forbidding their right to learn in their mother tongue. This situation has to be addressed as well.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - President! What is happening in the Crimea in these months and years is a good example of what retaliation a national minority can expect if the holder of political power classifies it as an enemy. There are also examples of this in European history, fortunately the methods used in Crimea today would be unthinkable in the European Union. With a question. However, this does not mean that national minorities are fully satisfied with their situation in the EU; on the contrary, there is a clear need for the EU institutions to address the special situation of some 60 million EU citizens who belong to national or linguistic minorities in the EU. -in. The EU must contribute to launching a dialogue between majority and minority, otherwise we will always only condemn violations outside the EU and then ignore our own problems. Then, if the situation gets angry enough, we will call on the parties involved to engage in dialogue, as in the case of Catalonia. Perhaps it would be more useful for the dialogue to take place before positions become rigid and the problems swept under the rug have consequences for the whole of the EU.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the human rights situation in the Crimean Peninsula has been deteriorating severely, as most recently documented in a report by the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights on 25 September. This report highlights the fact that Russian law has replaced Ukrainian law, in violation of international humanitarian law, that prisoners have been transferred to Russia (something which is prohibited under international humanitarian law), that there are systemic restrictions of fundamental freedoms, that there have been multiple failures to uphold the right to a fair trial and, not least, that there are arbitrary detentions, enforced disappearances, ill-treatment and torture. The three cases before us regrettably illustrate very well the worsening situation. On 11 September, the Deputy Chair of the Mejlis, Akhtem Chiygoz, was sentenced to eight years’ imprisonment for participating in a pre-annexation rally held in support of the territorial integrity of Ukraine. On 22 September, the journalist Mykola Semena received a two-and-a-half-year suspended prison sentence merely for doing his job and, on 27 September, the Deputy Chair of the Mejlis, Ilmi Umerov, was sentenced to two years in prison for defending Ukraine’s territorial integrity in television interviews. These three cases are clear violations of fundamental freedoms, particularly that of expression. In addition, the EU does not recognise the illegal annexation and, therefore, we do not recognise the application of Russian law in the peninsula, including the politically motivated sentences given to Mr Chiygoz, Mr Umerov and Mr Semena. The European External Action Service has issued a statement in each of these cases. The EU also raises the issue of human rights violations and abuses in Crimea in public statements in international forums. EU officials regularly meet human rights defenders and journalists from Crimea, to be well informed about the situation on the ground. Currently, we are following closely the situation of four Crimean Tatars detained on Monday. All illegally detained Ukrainian citizens in Crimea and Russia should be released and their right to legal counsel and access to consular officers must be fully respected. Access to health care must be ensured, there should be full, free and unhindered access to the peninsula for international human rights personnel. The EU remains unwavering in its support for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and does not recognise the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula, which is a violation of international law.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place at the end of the discussion.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: written. - After the European charade about Spain's brutal violence against the peace-loving Catalans, one may wonder with what credibility the EU defends human rights. Yet it remains our duty to stand up for the fate of persecuted political activists around the world. That is why our delegation supports this resolution. Moscow's persecution of Crimean Tatars continues incessantly. Today we add two of their leaders and a journalist to the list of political prisoners. Ilmi Umerov, Akhtem Chiygoz and Mykola Semena stood up for their people, culture and future. Enough to give them severe sentences after a mock trial. Locking up old and sick opponents is the cynical means for Putin to perpetuate the illegal annexation and cultural assimilation of Crimea. It is time for Russia to withdraw all political convictions and release all political prisoners. Finally, the sanctions against Russia should be further expanded and the judges involved in these mock trials should be sanctioned.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – The Russian occupation of the Ukrainian Crimean peninsula has inflicted grave human rights violations, especially concerning the rights of journalists and issues pertaining to freedom of speech. Crimean leaders, including Akhtem Chiygoz and Ilmi Umerov, are being prosecuted for opposing Russia’s annexation of Crimea. The same is true for journalists, like Mykola Semena, who has been a vocal critic of Russia’s occupation and suggested that Ukraine should have blockaded the peninsula. He was convicted of acting against the ‘territorial integrity of the Russian Federation’, leaving him with a two-year suspended sentence and three-year ban on public activities.  While Semena does not have to serve a prison sentence, he is banned from public activities, including journalism, which takes away his freedom of speech and expression. If he violates this ban, he will be imprisoned by the Russian authorities. Ukrainian officials are working to bring Semena back to the Ukraine. There is a dire need to hold Russia accountable for their violations of human rights and to bring justice for the victims of these violations.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in the Maldives (2017/2870 (RSP)).

name: Javier Nart
text: Author.- Mr President, more than 40 years ago Spain was a paradise for tourism: sun and paella.But, behind the sun and the paella, there was a dictatorship, there were people in jail, there was repression and there was no democracy.Maldives is exactly the same, but much worse.We have wonderful islands, extraordinary underwater depths, a corrupt, repressive and torturer regime.People who go to the Maldives forget about the people from Maldives, which is transcendent.A motion for a resolution has been presented proposing specific personal sanctions for those responsible for repression, but it has not been approved, and it is regrettable - and frankly it hurts your soul - since there was something fundamental, which is a campaignawareness-raising for tourists who want to go to the Maldives, who should be told that they are going to the paradise that is hell.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, I am deeply concerned about the worsening situation in the Maldives. President Abdulla Yameen and his government seem focused on increasing their authoritarian rule. Opposition leaders have been imprisoned, parliamentarians and journalists have been intimidated and threatened, and news organisations has been forced to close. All of this is deeply alarming. Added to this are the plethora of new laws that limit the freedoms of speech and of assembly, and there is now an end to a 60-year moratorium on the use of the death penalty. This all exhibits a deeply worrying trend towards a politicised judiciary and police, and it cannot be ignored that the Maldives now tops the table in terms of the number of ISIS recruits per capita of population. It is also deeply regrettable that the Maldives took the decision to leave the Commonwealth in 2016, demonstrating Yameen’s unwillingness to cooperate with international partners. We must now urge Yameen to uphold his country’s constitution, to protect democratic rights and to restore fundamental freedoms in line with international law and conventions. All political prisoners held on fabricated charges should be released, and the Presidential elections in 2018 should be free, fair and inclusive. It is vital for the future of the Maldives and its people that freedoms of assembly and expression are upheld for all.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: , author. - Mr President, far from the dream destination it represents for many tourists, especially Europeans, the Maldives seem to be sinking more and more into what one might call a form of obscurantism. Women are often the first victims, with sentences of lashes and the wearing of the hijab, which is more and more widespread. Children are also affected, with criminal liability set at ten years, and even seven years in some cases. Journalists and bloggers are particularly targeted, especially when they are not Muslims and, worse, when they are atheists. Yameen Rasheed, a young blogger of 29 years, murdered with 16 stab wounds, is a symbol of this. He knew he was threatened and had lodged a complaint, but in vain. Other victims include lawyers. Two-thirds of bar members were suspended in September and prisons are full of political prisoners. Finally, the death penalty was reinstated, although no execution has yet taken place, as five of the 17 convicted were minors at the time of the crime. The European Union, the Maldives’s largest trading partner, has the means to act in the interest of the people, but you still have to want to!

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, we are here today discussing once again the situation in the Maldives, which not only has not improved, but has got even worse. Through our vote we will surely support this resolution. However, I would like to underline that we are not actually taking any steps forward in comparison with the previous resolution. Indeed, a crucial part of the previous resolution is missing, namely the travel ban.  I genuinely think that the travel ban approach is by far the most effective tool we can use to have a high impact on the Maldivian Government and to offer a concrete and solid response to those who are violating human rights and international law in the Maldives. Considering that hundreds of thousands of European tourists travel to the Maldives every year, and taking into account that the government is clearly not concerned about any international recommendations or admonitions, I strongly believe that the travel ban may be one of the best options we have at our disposal. Indeed, the travel ban will produce the dramatic loss of a huge market share for the travel industry, which would make them vulnerable and surely keener to respect human rights.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author.- Mr President, the European Union has been active in the Maldives process for quite some time, but we do not think it is enough.That is why we have agreed across the political spectrum on this resolution, which is different in many respects, because it takes into account things that we have not previously accepted and reflected in our resolutions.Yes, it is often said that everyone can criticize, but criticism must be constructive and help with the solution.But unfortunately, despite our constructive solutions, the situation in the Maldives has no way out.The prosecution of opposition leaders, the restoration of the death penalty, must be abandoned.International obligations must be respected, as must the issue of religious respect.If the Maldives does not continue to comply with this, sanctions need to be considered, and this could be the ban on EU tourists traveling to this beautiful island.

name: Soraya Post
text: Author. - Mr President! Commissioner! My picture of the Maldives was atolls with a chalk-white beach and rolling palm trees - a little paradise in postcard format. This is the image that the Maldivian government wants the outside world to get from the country. And they have succeeded. Over one million tourists visit this island nation every year. However, there is another side that the rulers prefer not to show: that dissident politicians and civil society are subjected to harassment, that journalists and parliamentarians are imprisoned on unjustified grounds, that the government in the Maldives wants to resume the death penalty, even for children under 18 years. As a parliamentarian and feminist, I want to say that a secure civil society and an independent body of journalists are necessary parts of a democracy. The death penalty is in any case unthinkable and should be abolished, not reinstated. And to the Maldives, I want to say: Live up to democratic principles, live up to a genuine defense of human rights. Only then can we believe in your paradise in a postcard format.

name: Jean Lambert
text: author. – Mr President, I speak in my capacity as chair of Parliament’s Delegation for Relations with South Asia, which includes the Maldives. In fact, we have a visit planned there at the end of this month, but this resolution is separate in its motivation from that visit. However, we will welcome an opportunity to discuss our findings with everyone who is so concerned today on our return.  I think it is clear to say that we recognise the positive role that the Maldives is playing in terms of their international commitment on climate change and their cooperation with the European Union on issues of security, for example. However, as has been made very clear this morning, there are very deep concerns about issues of governance since the major constitutional changes of 2008. On our last visit, and since then, we have picked up on growing concern about the independence and impartiality of the judiciary at all levels, the recent suspension of one third of lawyers, the narrowing of the freedom of expression and the pressure on independent media. The recent murder of the blogger that people have referred to actually sent shockwaves throughout the Maldives, as well as the rest of the world, because murder is so rare in that society. I think all of us, as MPs, would be worried if we saw most of our party leaders in jail, facing criminal charges. So we need productive political dialogue, and we need a strengthening of independent bodies, such as the Human Rights Commission, so that we can see democracy move forward in the Maldives, as we all hope.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, under the presidency of Abdulla Yameen, the Maldives is in the process of shifting from a regime undergoing democratization to an authoritarian one. All the signs are there: freedom of expression severely questioned, journalists threatened with death, the judicial system increasingly controlled by the government. The example of the suspension of a third of the country's lawyers is, in this context, only the latest sign. The government of the day is doing everything it can to destroy the political opposition, including militarily occupying the parliamentary stage to prevent votes that do not suit it. Under these conditions, I support the introduction of individual sanctions against all those who cause these violations of human rights. I believe that these sanctions should not be lifted until all political prisoners are released, but also until a minimum democratic framework is restored so that the upcoming elections can take place freely.

name: Wajid Khan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, just a few days ago at the UN General Assembly, the Maldives Foreign Minister said the following words: ‘Looking to cultivate a culture of respect for human rights at home and abroad is our goal. We believe we have been successful’. The Maldives Government wants us to believe that the country is a young democracy and a tourist paradise, but this just isn’t the case. Recently one third of all practising lawyers were suspended for calling for the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. Numerous prisoners are currently under death sentence with serious concerns about the fairness of their trials, and at least five of those convicted are under 18 years old.  The blogger and prominent human rights defender Yameen Rasheed was killed in April. Sadly, he is another victim of the wider crackdown on the freedom of expression in the Maldives. My Group is alarmed at the deteriorating situation, as well as the continued harassment of the media, political opponents and civil society. We ask the External Action Service and Member States to make full use of all instruments at their disposal in order to promote human rights and democratic principles. We call on the Maldives authorities to stop ruling with an iron fist and enter into a genuine dialogue with opposition parties and civil society, ensuring free and fair elections. We also urge them to reinstate the moratorium on the death penalty. It is time to back up words with action and to embrace human rights and justice. It is in the interest of all Maldivians.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: , on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the Maldives: sun, coconut trees, white sand beaches, turquoise waters and heavenly hotels. The postcard is idyllic on the front, but on the back, Sharia law dictates. The death penalty was reinstated there three years ago, including for children. President Yameen’s regime is “kind” to only enforce sentences when they come of age. The intimidation and assassination of journalists and bloggers who defend freedom of expression are numerous: Ismail Hilath, Yameen Rasheed and all the others. Lawyers were suspended for daring to demand respect for the rule of law, and Mohamed Nasheed, the first democratically elected president, was sentenced to 13 years in prison. The Maldives is also one of the largest suppliers, proportionately, of jihadist reinforcements to the Islamic State, and I have not yet spoken of women, with the public stoning of adulterous women, early marriage and rapes. The list is endless. Under the beach, it’s hell! So you might as well know it when you click and book your vacation. A million tourists every year is a weapon of mass deterrence when diplomacy fails.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Maldives: when heaven becomes hell. We have already dealt in this House with the deterioration of civil liberties, the threats, the torture that members of the opposition and journalists, bloggers, human rights defenders and ordinary citizens are undergoing in the beautiful atoll of the Indian Ocean, the dream of millions of tourists. unaware of what is really going on. When it seemed that the situation could not worsen further, the declaration of President Abdul Gayoom came instead, who clearly expressed his intention to resume executions in the country from the end of September. According to him, executions are necessary to maintain public order and the values ​​of the Maldives. If this isn't a red line, what can it be, then connect? I repeat the appeal we already made in December 2015, also to counter the selective deafness that the Union is increasingly manifesting: we need targeted sanctions against those responsible for this authoritarian drift and if there is no progress, we must have the courage to put table also a total travel ban for our tourists. And I make a second appeal to the Member States: inform your citizens that outside the golden cages of holiday resorts, hell is materializing. And finally, a final warning: you have ignored our requests but to date it is painfully clear that "business as usual" not only does not represent a viable path but is interpreted by our counterpart as a sign of weakness, an endorsement to continue undisturbed their own repressive policies towards civil society which we should instead defend. To persevere at this point would be diabolical.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I come to similar conclusions to this report in many ways, but for different reasons. I note that paragraph 15, the text on female genital mutilation, is calling only for laws to be enforced. It is a barbaric practice and, quite frankly, it is something which also happens in the European Union and gets brushed under the carpet. It even happens in my own country, and yet there are no successful prosecutions for it. So I would make exactly the same call to ourselves. When it comes to the death penalty, I have to say that my opposition to the death penalty is one which is practical. Simply to say that: if there were the rule of law, if there were fair trials, if we knew that it was being done in a manner that actually represented justice for a lethal crime, then I would be saying that it is the sovereign democratic right of that country to take its own decision on that issue. My concern is that what is happening here is that we are speaking of the death penalty for children, of a politicised judiciary, and of a country where there is arbitrary detention, serious concerns over extrajudicial actions and the murder of anti—government bloggers, for example the case of Yameen Rasheed. So that is not really what is happening, and therefore I take a much dimmer view. We have a country which has left the Commonwealth and where there is a huge amount of recruitment going on for ISIS. Finally, I will finish by just noting the bill on the protection of reputation and good name and freedom of expression, which seeks to clamp down on freedom of expression in that country. It is just so Orwellian to say that they have a law for freedom of expression, which is actually being used for completely the opposite purpose.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have asked for a catch-the-eye statement because, throughout my time in politics, I have been devoting myself to the death penalty in the world and watching the recent misuse or use of this instrument increase,which we Europeans absolutely reject.The death penalty is the most serious form of criminal justice repression, it is irreversible and it is very sad that the Maldives is another country in the world that does not want to respect the moratorium on this inhuman punishment and that wants to restore the death penalty.That is why I support this resolution.What other colleagues have said about the break-up of democracy and the rule of law in the Maldives, but I am particularly interested in the death penalty.I would also like to mention that the Maldives is ready to execute juveniles, which is a particularly inhumane form and abuse of this punishment, and we must protest against that, which is why I support this resolution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the Maldives is the worst performer in the world in protecting human rights. There is no freedom of expression, there is no democratic pluralism, the right to assemble is forbidden, dissidents, journalists, bloggers are persecuted. The licenses of 56 lawyers have been revoked. The militiamen are dispersing the protests with impunity. An unacceptable situation, which, of course, is being denounced by all the wings here in our Parliament. At the same time, even young people under the age of 18 are sentenced to death. Very specific measures must therefore be taken against the Maldivian government. Jihadism is also developing, which is particularly dangerous. More than 300,000 Europeans are currently traveling from the UK, Germany, Italy and France alone for tourism. A travel instruction should be issued prohibiting any travel. Only then will the Maldives government be forced to put its house in order.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Maldives is a small state and we are returning to it several times in this House.That, I think, testifies to a lot.The sun-drenched skies, Europeans spend their holidays here and then find out or find out at all that they are innocently locked up in the criminals there, that there is torture, intimidation, that even changes are to take place to bring the executions to the legal order.I think that these things should be known to Europeans, which is why I agree with my colleagues who have said that, above all, we should inform the European public, this is our very strong card in the diplomatic efforts that the European Commission and the services should have.The EU in this matter.I am convinced that we can force this state to negotiate changes that clearly go against our beliefs, which is certainly the execution of juveniles.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, in 2008 the Maldives made a promising transition from 30 years of authoritarian rule to a democratic system, through multiparty elections. The EU is monitoring the human rights and political situation in the country and has expressed a number of concerns. There is a worrying trend of reduced freedom of expression and freedom of association, highlighted most recently by the suspension of 56 lawyers for submitting a petition highlighting concerns with the judiciary. Opposition leaders are imprisoned or restricted in their movements. After the unprecedented lockdown of the parliament by security forces on 24 July 2017, there was an intensified crackdown on opposition legislators. Some journalists and media professionals also face intimidation and harassment. On 25 July 2017 the EU delegation accredited to the Maldives, with nine other embassies, made a local statement to the effect that: ‘It is essential that the freedoms of assembly and expression are upheld for all. Opposition politicians and members of civil society must be able to conduct their rightful duties without fear of intimidation or arrest.’ In late August the authorities agreed to host an electoral follow-up mission. I welcome that decision, which shows the authorities’ openness to discuss even challenging topics. Follow-up to the implementation of the previous EU recommendations would be a good framework for dialogue before the upcoming presidential election planned for November 2018. There has been a de facto moratorium on the death penalty for more than 60 years. Whereas the current administration continues publicly to maintain a commitment to resuming executions, there has not been an execution for more than half a century. The European Union and its Member States will continue to hold a strong and principled position against the death penalty in all circumstances and all cases. Several statements have been issued by the European External Action Service calling for the de facto moratorium on the death penalty to be upheld as a step towards its abolition. Radicalisation and criminality are on the rise in the Maldives. The brutal murder of blogger ... (The President interrupted the speaker) Mr President, radicalisation and criminality are on the rise in the Maldives. The brutal murder of blogger and human rights activist Yameen Rasheed in April 2017 testifies to this trend. On the other hand, the EU and the Maldives are strong partners in the fight against climate change, which remains one of the important areas of mutual interest. Member States have major investments in the tourist sector in the Maldives. Every year between 300 000 and 500 000 European tourists travel to the Maldives. It is important, in the dialogue with the authorities, to ensure the safety and security of these tourists as well as Maldivian citizens, through cooperation to prevent terrorism and violent extremism. To conclude, for several years we have held an annual dialogue to exchange views on issues of concern and issues of common interest. The last annual EU—Maldives policy dialogue was hosted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Malé in May 2017 and we intend to maintain this dialogue.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place at the end of the discussion.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The situation of human rights violations in the Maldives and the gradual deterioration of democratic standards is worrying. Not to be overlooked is the growing presence of authoritarian tendencies in the Maldives, as well as the promulgation of a new defamation law criminalizing “defamatory” speech or a law requiring the written permission of the police to hold protests in Malé. Freedom of assembly and freedom of the media should be guaranteed, not violated. Censorship of the media is totally unjustified because freedom and independence of the media is a fundamental tool of democracy. The European Union must promote the rule of law, including in the Maldives, with all available instruments so that the existing lack of judicial independence can be eliminated. The promotion of democracy, human rights and the rule of law is the cornerstone of the European Union's foreign policy. I call for a fair trial for the arrested journalists and political opponents because the arbitral awards are unacceptable. I support the motion for a resolution on violations of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law, and I believe that the Maldives needs EU development assistance and close monitoring of the human rights situation and the political situation in this country.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see minutes)

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, my Group calls for an oral amendment for the deletion of paragraph 15. We have been advised by the External Action Service that it is factually incorrect. Oral amendment to delete paragraph 15, please.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, as a result of advice from the External Action Service, my Group has been asked to add the word ‘former’ before ‘leader’, as he is no longer technically the leader of his party. This is just a factual error which needs correcting.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE). –
text: Mr President!Do you know what the problem is with the European Public Prosecutor's Office?When we talk about this, countries like Sweden, Malta, Poland and Hungary say "Oh, we do not want to leave much power to the EU, that is to make a federal Europe" and so on.Then the crime happens, of course.Then it turns out that you can not investigate it because it is supranational.Then the same countries complain that the EU does not do enough against crime, that the EU is not effective and so on.It's absolutely amazing.Crime and crime are now transnational.It is done by the gangs that move across borders and exploit our weakness, not being able to fight such crimes.If you want to fight it - and it's about trafficking, drugs, smuggling, arms smuggling - then you have to cooperate at European level.That Sweden chooses to stand outside that cooperation is completely incomprehensible to me.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, let me justify why I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the Council regulation establishing enhanced cooperation in setting up the European Public Prosecutor's Office.Combating damage to the EU's budget and financial interests is extremely important precisely because it is about harming European taxpayers themselves.The proposal to set up the Office has undergone significant positive changes, such as the decentralization of the system, the deletion of the article on the Single Judicial Area and others.I am aware that enhanced cooperation in the case of the establishment of a new institution is not common, so questions arise.On the other hand, no one doubts that this will lead to a shift in the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which could help to strengthen the fight against the misuse of European funds, which I consider to be crucial.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - President!I myself supported the adoption of this report.I consider the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to be a very important institution, all the more so because I believe that this has been forced by life, to a level of fraud at the expense of the European Union budget.It is particularly painful for me that there are some countries, including my own country, Hungary, whose government has not signed or joined this cooperation.I have a hard heart, but I can say that all those who want to hide from joint European control will be deprived of the sums that this prosecutor's office is also called upon to monitor.They should not be given an iron until they realize that they also have a place in this prosecution system.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, reinforced cooperation would also be very useful to monitor how European funds are used in the different regions of this Union, because, for example, when we have been paying attention to Catalonia all week, other regions of Spain take advantage This is to repress in the same way - that is, with violent police charges - legitimate citizen protests, such as that of the residents of Murcia, who are demanding that their city not be divided in two with a wall of five meters of high and nine kilometers long that will isolate more than one hundred thousand people to allow the arrival of high speed. High speed, by the way, of which millions of euros have disappeared along the way and nobody knows where or how. From here I appeal to the responsibility of the Government to demand that the construction of that wall cease immediately and that the roads be buried, as the residents of Murcia have been requesting for more than thirty years and as the Regional government of Murcia in 2006.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) will fill serious international gaps. The prevention and prosecution of offences against the EU budget and the financial interests of the EU are currently within the exclusive competence of Member States. The EU Anti-fraud Office OLAF, Eurojust and Europol do not have a mandate to conduct criminal investigations, and sometimes their opinions are ignored by national authorities. We have worrying information that, in some Member States, national investigators are under pressure from local politicians, and they are not interested in the proper investigation of the use of money from European funds. We have now taken a small but very important step. We have started to create a European system. We should not be confused by the fact that only 20 EU Member States will participate in the creation of the EPPO or by the very limited nature of its mandate. As we have often seen in EU history, big reforms all start with very careful first decisions. I voted in favour.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because I support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and share the need for institutional measures at supranational European level to effectively prosecute fraud and other crimes affecting the financial interests of EU Member States. Bulgaria is part of those 20 member states that want to start enhanced cooperation for the establishment of such a service. I am pleased to see that in its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs approves the Council's decisions. The protection and prosecution of crimes against the Union budget and the financial interests of the Union are the exclusive competence of the Member States. OLAF, Eurojust and Europol do not have a mandate to conduct a criminal investigation and the functioning European Public Prosecutor's Office will fill this institutional gap. I will be happy if this happens during the forthcoming Bulgarian presidency.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in the end I did not support this report, I abstained. I have been dealing with the issue of the European Public Prosecutor for more than ten years. I was in charge of this topic when I was a member of the government in the Czech Republic, and I must say that even after those ten years, there are still a number of important professional objections to this institute. Experts still claim that the establishment of a new office may, on the contrary, lead to the prolongation of some criminal cases by sending those cases "to Brussels", preparing files, etc. It should be borne in mind that ultimately deciding on those criminal cases will have as well as in the hands of the national courts of each Member State. In short, this remains here, and if the reason for setting up a European Public Prosecutor is distrust of national judicial systems, of national legal systems, it must be borne in mind that this institute will not solve it as such. That is why I abstained, and I will be glad if the practice may refute my objections.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted against this proposal.It is probably known that both my political faction and my own party have long opposed the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor.There are both political and legal reasons for this.For those political reasons, I would say, above all, that the establishment of this function actually introduces another element of federalization into the system of European institutions, and that is something we do not support.There are, of course, very relevant legal objections, especially those that, at the same end point, it will be the national authorities that will be responsible for the verdict.And in any case, it seems to us that the equipment of the national authorities - judicial, investigative - is sufficient and that their credibility is so great that they do not have to be subject to any additional control or the establishment of such a body.So we say no to the European Public Prosecutor.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, normally I abstain on matters that do not affect the United Kingdom. The European Public Prosecutor’s Office is being introduced through enhanced cooperation, but, in this case, it will affect the United Kingdom because that Office will have the power to issue European arrest warrants and, consequently, the power to detain British citizens living in the UK. I therefore voted against this resolution, and I note that it is yet another situation where those who support European Union membership in the United Kingdom have been less than forthcoming about the true nature of the EU project.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I strongly and heartily support this proposal. We no longer have the luxury of turning a blind eye to the ongoing fraudulent use of the European Union’s funds. It is estimated that the EU loses around EUR 600 million per year due to fraud. This cannot go on and on. By unifying the work of national prosecutors under the new European Public Prosecutor’s Office, which will be leading the work of European delegated prosecutors, they will be able to perform investigations in a cooperative manner using the common procedures and remaining in line with national laws.  Such synchronised cooperation between the Member States will help to address systematic drawbacks and properly investigate and put an end to these crimes.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, supporters of this proposal tell us that crime does not recognise national borders. They say this as though it were an original insight. Of course crime crosses borders, and for many years democratic nation states have collaborated without supranational institutions. We have the Hague Convention; we have Interpol; we have extradition treaties; we recognise time spent in another country’s prison. This is not about cooperation; this is about the creation of a federal legal system and a federal prosecution service, giving the European Union the ultimate attribute of statehood, namely the ability to use coercive force against its own citizens. Yes, sure, starting with questions like fraud against the EU budget and racketeering is just the way the FBI and the federal prosecutors started in the United States. However, the eventual aim is of course for it to become the basis of a legal system for a country called Europe.  We absolutely believe in cooperation in the field of crime and policing. After the United Kingdom has left, you will be able to rely on our continued collaboration, but this is exactly why we are leaving.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the fight against fraud throughout the European Union is becoming more complex every year, and many times it seems that fraudsters and criminals are a step forward. They know how to exploit "holes" in the current system of legislation in each Member State, use cross-border trade and divide their business activities so that they cannot be prosecuted in several Member States at once. I supported the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation implementing enhanced cooperation for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and I am glad that Slovakia is among the countries that support this proposal. Every year, the European Union loses billions in tax fraud, which we could invest in young people, for employment growth and the eradication of poverty in the EU, but also in the much-needed science and research. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office will certainly facilitate and streamline the work of OLAF, Eurojust and Europol, which do not have a mandate to conduct criminal investigations but can detect them and pass the results on to the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - I voted against this proposal for a European Public Prosecutor's Office, aiming in theory, at least initially, at financial crimes relating to the European budget, but we know very well that, as several speakers before me have said, it this is just the start. What we want is to establish a real system which, one day perhaps, will make it possible to prosecute the offenses of expression which have excessively multiplied in the law of certain Member States. This is how hundreds of people are prosecuted and imprisoned, especially in Germany, for expressing dissenting points of view on the history of the Second World War. This is how Jean-Marie Le Pen is prosecuted for homophobia, who declared that "homosexuals are like salt, if there is a little of it, it spices up, if there is any. too much, it's indigestible ”, or that we take the ridicule of suing him also because he said that the presence of the Roma was irritating in Nice. In other words, maybe tomorrow MEPs will be arrested on the basis of an arrest warrant issued by the prosecution for such expressing offenses. I’m sure that’s the trend we’re going, and that’s why I’m fighting it.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! The European Union is constantly expanding its powers to include ever new areas and this evolution could be debated if this enlargement was accompanied by more solidarity and responsibility. On the contrary, it is all accompanied by more and more arrogance. Unfortunately, a display of such arrogance was given by Commissioner Jourová, who once again threatened with de facto sanctions or the use of selective justice, some special supervision, to those countries that would not accept the competences of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. On this matter, my Conservatives and Reformists group have already addressed the President of the European Commission, but unfortunately you can see that - so to speak - Ms Jourová is just saying aloud what her colleagues in the European Commission are thinking quietly or leaving when speaking out loud another. In fact, the European Union is led in a terrible direction and only a change of its powers can repair our relations.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
