text: - (IT) Mr President, the number of prisoners in Europe exceeds more than a third the number of places available. In some Member States, including Italy, the situation is dramatic. I voted in favor of this report, not least because it clearly states that there is no correlation between the severity of penalties and the drop in the crime rate. The aim of the States is not revenge, but the defeat of crime. And to achieve this goal, the harshest sentences are not needed, but more just and useful to recover the prisoners. It must be clear that the deprivation of liberty must not degenerate into the deprivation of dignity. For this reason it is important to study alternative measures to traditional prison, to promote cultural recovery, training and education actions that open new perspectives to inmates. I met inmates who were Mafia killers and today they are workers, artisans, artists and other inmates who were not criminals, but only poor who became mafia in prison. The difference is between an experience and a torture.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think that the main tasks of prisons are not only to be an instrument for punishment and isolation, but also to be institutions that prevent future crimes and help prisoners return to normal life. This cannot happen if the prisoners live in bad conditions, with overcrowded rooms, or if experienced prisoners are held in the same cells as young people convicted for minor crimes. We should establish dignified conditions of detention, create possibilities for socialisation, encourage rehabilitation and reintegration into society, develop educational facilities for prisoners, and ensure a safer living and working environment for both prisoners and staff.  I’m worried that the Latvian Government will postpone a project to build a new, modern prison in my country, and thus the closing of three old, overcrowded prisons. This is not an act of political wisdom, nor is it in the interest of the society. However, I voted in favour of this report yet again.

name: John Flack (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this is the first time I have spoken here since taking my seat in July. I wanted to wait until I actually had something worth saying and something I could speak knowledgeably about – not as a prisoner, as has been the experience of some here, but as a long-serving British magistrate. I have visited many types of prisons, and have seen for myself the good, the bad and the downright frightening. These experiences have led me to vote against this report, not because of its good intentions, but because it does not adequately address the most urgent issue facing prisons across Europe, as well as in Norwich, Bedford, Chelmsford and in the other prisons across my region: that is the rise of radical and violent ideologies and terrorist radicalisation.  Secondly, in its utopian call for fewer prisons, it goes far beyond the competences of this Parliament. These are matters that should, and indeed must, be left to individual nation states. For these reasons, and several others, I voted against.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted against this report because my colleague Bergeron has focused on improving living conditions, the lack of care and medical care and the reintegration of prisoners, but very little attention has been paid to the problem of the growing phenomenon of the spread of radical and violent ideologies and terrorist radicalization in many prisons in the Member States of the European Union. Furthermore, although the report explicitly states that prison conditions and prison management are the responsibility of Member States, in many respects it goes too far, calling on Member States to adopt independent prison monitoring mechanisms and to allocate adequate resources. to renovate and modernize prisons and to promote alternatives to prisoners. That is why, because of these shortcomings, I voted against the report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, first of all, if you want to have fewer prisons, you have to start by having fewer criminals. You need to cut the rate of offending. That means we need to be in a position where we can cut the rate of reoffending by people who come out of prison. I believe fundamentally in rehabilitation. I believe that it is good for society if you can take people and put them back on the straight and narrow. If you want to do that, however, you have to do it with teeth. You have to make sure that people who get early release from prison have got three things: that they behave in prison; that they develop their education whilst in prison; and, fundamentally, that they get a job to go to, so they can break the cycle of reoffending when they come out. If we do all of those things, then, yes, of course society should invest in helping prisoners to rehabilitate. We hear much about the carrot but we don’t hear very much about the stick when it comes to anything related to our judicial system. I really do believe we need to make sure that those people who do not engage in the process have got tough prison conditions, and that prison then becomes for them a place of punishment. Lastly, what we are completely missing in all of this is that this is not a matter for the European Union. It is for Member States to decide on their own prison systems.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF).
text: - Mr President, prison overcrowding and poor detention conditions are obviously a reality in prisons in Europe. My country, France, has distinguished itself over the course of its successive governments by a general deterioration of its prison capacity. It is certainly essential to modernize and renovate prisons, however, some solutions advocated in this report seem dangerous to me, in particular the encouragement to resort to non-custodial sentences or measures, which once again reflects the triumph of penal laxity. In this age of Islamist radicalism, the explosion of delinquency and terrorism, nothing justifies the modification of sentences. It is to be regretted that, in this report, the phenomenon of radicalization is never associated with Islamism. Also, how do you fight a problem without even naming it? I would remind you that radical Islam took the lives of two young girls in Marseille last Sunday precisely because society forgot that it was necessary to permanently lock up or expel repeat offenders. This is the reason why I voted against this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the prison situation in many States of the Union is worrying. Many prisons are in a situation of saturation or have already exceeded it. The resources allocated, both to the reintegration of prisoners and to accompanying programs for parole, are alarmingly insufficient. Only one piece of information: the rate of recidivism exceeds 50% in some Union states. Unfortunately, the protection of fundamental rights and human dignity, which are crucial in any democratic society, has been repeatedly challenged by the European Court of Human Rights and the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and Punishment o Inhuman or Degrading Treatment. Systems focused solely on punishment are ineffective and often counterproductive. We believe that our societies deserve much more than growing prison populations and alarming recidivism rates, and that is why we call for the implementation of mediation and reparative justice systems, the implementation and adequate budgeting of reintegration programs during and after the condemnation and end of the privatization processes of public prisons.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament has no competence to set standards for prisons in the Member States. This is up to the Member States themselves, it is a question of subsidiarity, we cannot try to determine them. Our Slovak state prisons have two goals: to re-educate criminals and, of course, to punish them, but to re-educate them. What should bother the Union is the personal change of those already in prison and the prevention of radicalization. They have to change for the better. But what do we see? The spread of jihadism, and that is the scourge of today's society, which is causing terrorist attacks on civilians, and we must support groups and measures that succeed in truly changing people in the heart and inside and in the positive direction of their lives. Workers of Christian organizations and Christian preachers see how the lives of prisoners across Europe have changed in the past through the power of the gospel of Jesus Christ. They see this transformation of men and women who know how to help others today, so instead of jihadists we need a gospel in our prisons with a message of hope and peace, because Jesus Christ is the one who turns a criminal's life into a man of peace, peace and love.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we Socialists and, in particular, Spanish Socialists welcome this own-initiative report on the prison situation in Europe. And we have especially supported the emphasis it places on the reintegration and re-socialization of the prison population. But, precisely in the final vote, we have chosen to abstain because section 29 of the Resolution, indiscriminately and generically and with harsh language, literally uses the verb "condemn" when it refers to the policy of territorialized distribution of prisoners throughout the national territory —which, with some critical accent, is known as the policy of dispersal or removal of prisoners—, as if this inflicted additional damage and was incompatible with resocialization. Quite the opposite. It turns out that resocialization is impossible when we are faced with organized crime, the crime that in Italy is called mafioso stampo, with the radicalization produced by jihadism and, unfortunately, with terrorist crime - as we have seen in Spain - where the Territorial dispersion of prisoners precisely helps resocialization, and concentration in a single prison produces the opposite effect: the impossibility of resocialization, reeducation and reintegration, precisely because the radicalization of the inmate population takes place, within the prisons themselves . This is why we believe that this explanation of vote is necessary in the final vote, as it was impossible to vote individually and separately on paragraph 29.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the European Action Plan for the Social Economy by Jens Nilsson, Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso, Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea, Marie-Christine Vergiat, Sven Giegold, Elena Gentile, Agnes Jongerius, Brando Benifei, Clara Eugenia Aguilera García, Ernest Urtasun, Evelyn Regner, Pina Picierno, Izaskun Bilbao Barandica, Jan Keller, Jean Lambert, Jean-Paul Denanot, Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz, Nessa Childers, Nicola Danti, Patrizia Toia, Ramón JáureguiRenata Briano, Sergio Gaetano Cofferati, Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto, Guillaume Balas, Nicola Caputo, Simona Bonafè, Damiano Zoffoli, Enrico Gasbarra, Marita Ulvskog, Jytte Guteland, Olle Ludvigsson, Anna Hedh, Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, Elena Valenciano, Sofia Ribeiro. Becker, Georgi Pirinski, Enrique Guerrero Salom and Maria Arena (O-000070/2017 - B8-0602 / 2017) (2017/2877 (RSP)).

name: Jens Nilsson
text: questioner. - Madam President! In December 2015, the Council adopted conclusions on the promotion of the social economy as an important driving force for economic and social development in Europe. It was a milestone, it was the first time that the member states of the Council came to conclusions on this sector. It did so because it sees the potential of this sector in terms of the social economy, which covers a wide range of business models - cooperatives, of course, non-profit associations, mutuals, foundations - and they play an important role in achieving more of EU objectives. That is what the 28 countries say unanimously in the conclusions. They also say that this sector contributes to smart and sustainable growth for all. Smart and sustainable growth with jobs with fair conditions, social cohesion, social innovation and environmental protection. This is not a small sector in Europe, there are two million companies in this sector. They employ over 14.5 million people and account for 8% of the EU's total gross domestic product. Activities in the social economy always reinvest their profits, are driven primarily by social and environmental goals and not primarily by dividends to passive owners. This allows these companies to set a good example in tackling some of our common challenges in Europe. They create high-quality jobs, support people's integration processes and promote an economy based on democratic participation - and this is not least important. This is something that Parliament has emphasized in the past, not least in the report on a European pillar of social rights. This sector means a great deal at all levels. Locally, because here people are mobilized for social cohesion in democratic structures. As an old mayor in my hometown, I know how important the non-profit forces are, how important the cooperatives are, how important people's will to create a good society locally is. A municipality that mine would not be able to do without this sector. Regionally, it means a lot, creates jobs and growth. Many regions also have this sector as a strategic asset in their development work. Globally, this sector also means a lot, we have received proof of this during the financial crisis. And many are now saying, including the OECD and others, that this sector has a stabilized effect on a market economy that is liberal and may not always be able to be as stable as it should be. Not least as an example: There are studies that show that companies in this sector coped with the financial crisis much better than many other sectors. Just look at the cooperative banks, as reports have shown, the crisis coped much better than many others. In 2016, the Commission called on the Bratislava Declaration on the Social Economy, signed by ten Member States, and also on the report of the Commission's own expert group, the GECES Group, to draw up a European Action Plan for the Social Economy. With these calls and with the unanimity of the Council on these issues, it will be easy for the Commission to say: 'This is the way we should go'. In May 2017, a number of Member States adopted the Madrid Declaration, calling on the Commission to develop a European Action Plan in its work program for 2018. This is to stimulate a sector that actually promotes social activities in Europe and its capacity for innovation. In addition, in its opinion on start - ups and expanding companies, the Economic and Social Committee called on the Commission to bring together all ongoing and new initiatives in support of social enterprises by drawing up a communication with an action plan for the social economy. There are many who want this action plan. There are many who see that this sector could play a very active role in a Europe that is growing, and that is growing on human terms. This sector could contribute much more than it does today.So my question is: what is the Commission doing in response to these calls from Parliament, from the Council, from different Member States to promote companies in the social economy?Does the Commission plan to draw up an action plan for the social economy in accordance with these requests?

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank all the Members for their questions on the social economy. Clearly, this is a key issue for all of us. First, the Commission agrees with Parliament on the importance of the social economy for Europe. Delivering on a more social and fair Europe is a key priority for the Commission. Earlier this year we launched a reflection paper on Europe’s social dimension and the pillar of social rights. This has started a process with citizens, social partners and the European institutions and governments to find responses to the challenges our societies and citizens face. These challenges require innovative social and economic models to deliver more growth and well—being in Europe. The social economy is a core part of this move. It combines solidarity with innovative answers to societal challenges. It answers the growing demand among European entrepreneurs and consumers for a new way of doing business responsibly and sustainably.  Social economy is not another economy; it is part of the wider economy. It makes sense to invest in it, so we want to see the sector succeed. We have been working with you and other stakeholders to promote the growth of the sector. Over the last years we have taken several measures and our 2011 Social Business Initiative. We have encouraged Member States to develop favourable conditions for the social economy and social enterprises to grow. For instance, the social economy and social enterprises are priorities of the European Social Fund.  We also recognise that there is untapped potential and barriers which hamper the development of the sector in many countries, so we are continuing to develop and implement new measures. The expert group on social entrepreneurship issued some recommendations and we are taking forward a number of them such as increasing visibility, making funds more easily available or enforcing and reinforcing the legal environment. We have carefully analysed the different proposals presented in different EU political documents and intergovernmental declarations. As a result, we decided to launch a number of new actions to stimulate the development of the social economy. We announced these in our Start—up and Scale—up initiative last year. It would be important for any future initiative after 2018, such as a Social Business Initiative II, to be based on the evaluation of the situation after the current Start-up and Scale-up initiative has been fully implemented. Our actions rest on five pillars: access to finance, access to markets, development of better framework conditions, new technologies and social innovation and the international dimension of social economic actors. We have made good progress but there are still a number of measures that we announced and that need to be implemented. We are currently working on finalising all this work so that the remaining measures will be implemented next year at the latest.  Given all this work, we think that it would be premature to launch an additional action plan for the social economy at this stage. We want to first deliver what we have promised and then let us see if more needs to be done. We are relying on the support of our informal task force on social economy and social enterprises, involving a number of Commission services. Honourable Members, once again we fully agree with you on the importance of the social economy for Europe. The Commission adopted this week the Public Procurement Package and it will help also to boost social economy and social enterprises. We will continue to work with all stakeholders to ensure that the voice of the social economy is heard across the whole of Europe. We want to see more enterprises and more innovations change lives.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, for the information and measures with which I can agree. I would like to remind you that the social economy is an area of ​​business that takes a very diverse form depending on the legal systems of the Member States, and in general a social enterprise can be characterized by reinvesting all the profits generated in its core business. Social enterprises are therefore based on the need to help specific people, communities and integrate people into society. This makes social enterprises important for society, and it is no coincidence that we are also talking about them at European level. The Council conclusions of December 2015, which, by the way, are very successful, state that the social economy contributes to a number of key EU objectives and is also a sector that has weathered the economic crisis much better than other sectors and is gaining increasing recognition at European level. . I would like to remind you that we have around 2 million social enterprises at European level and employ 14.5 million people. I think this is a very strong sector. I think each of us knows one of the social enterprises. They include disadvantaged people - in short, at risk - and create very important conditions for their inclusion. In this situation, I would also like to emphasize the role of the churches, which create the conditions for the charitable work of millions of people throughout Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we should support the voluntary initiative of companies, and no action plan is needed at the moment.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Commissioner, when you talk about European plans and the social economy, you need to look at and discuss, above all, the huge issue of the drastic income and wage gap in Eastern and Western Europe. This huge gap is forcing many young people from Eastern Europe to leave their homelands and move west to make a living there, and this is turning a huge demographic problem in these areas. This is where the role of the Commission lies, and that is what you need to write in your plan - this is one of the most important things. It must be worked on. The Commission is obliged to sanction the states that introduce protectionist policies and hinder the development of business. The Commission is obliged to react when, for example, legislation is passed in Germany that targets entrepreneurs in the East. In France there is similar legislation, in Belgium there is similar legislation, in Italy there is similar legislation that prevents companies from the East from operating in the common market and thus violates the very idea of ​​a single common market. This is the Commission's obligation to respect the four fundamental freedoms and the Treaties. This is perhaps the only important task that the Commission should pursue when it comes to the social economy. There are such protectionist measures in the field of transport, in the field of construction ... The false thesis of President Macron about the so-called social dumping is actually a covert protectionism on the part of a number of western companies. And this is your task and you have to cope with it. Circumstances will force you to do so. This is the future of Europe to talk about on these issues.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for all the efforts you have made, but I believe that the action plan to which this question refers is not an option, I believe that it is an obligation. In the Basque Country, the social economy is one of the keys that explain why we have endured the crisis better than in the Spanish economy. This is a type of entrepreneurship that better fixes employment, that stimulates more the incorporation of talent into business and that generates sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth; it brings positive values ​​to the rest of the economic system and offers hope, the other way of conceiving and using profits, that of returning capital to its role as an instrument at the service of the real economy and not vice versa. For this reason, a clear and homogeneous legal and fiscal framework is needed at the Union level, for the social economy and for all its forms of expression, and that is a clear and real obstacle to developing a way of undertaking. and work that should be promoted at European level and that can contribute a lot to 2020 development.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Jens Nilsson, because I believe that it is to him that we owe the inclusion on the agenda of this debate devoted to the social economy and not to businesses social. Yes, the social economy is an important sector that does not get the recognition it deserves. Yes, that's two million companies, 14.5 million employees, 8% of the European Union's GDP, a strong resilience to the crisis, as Ms. Bilbao has just told us. These are companies which define themselves first of all by their status: cooperatives, mutual societies, associations, foundations, and which are not reduced only to SMEs, Commissioner! They can have very different sizes. Even if many of them are characterized by a strong territorial anchoring, their activities are not purely social and even less limited to only the most disadvantaged groups, even if there is no doubt that many of them have a purpose. social. They operate in all areas of the economy. Confusion, voluntary or not, intentional or not, between the social economy and solidarity-based businesses should not lead to large companies doing social washing cheaply. The Social Impact Bonds project in this area gave rise to many questions and a need for clarification. Some social economy enterprises, especially the most fragile of them, in this period of public money shortage, need new financing possibilities. Private capital can provide this, but guarantees are then needed, and these companies need even more access to appropriate European funding. I will insist once again on the need to work towards a status that is common to all of these companies, namely a status of a partnership (in English, Personal Companies). Such a status would not solve everything, but it is one of the surest ways of allowing these companies to have their specificity recognized, of not forcing them to dissolve into the dominant model of the capital company. Especially when they carry out cross-border activities, they want to expand their activities internationally. It is a way of safeguarding their specificity. Social and solidarity economy companies favor the long term and reinvestment of profits, and not the race for profit and short-term profitability. They are undoubtedly, by this very fact, carriers of social as much as economic innovations. They are strong job creators. This sector, which makes an essential contribution to the promotion of a more sustainable and inclusive model of growth and development, not only in the European Union, but also everywhere in the world, needs an appropriate framework to develop. . So today is the time to develop and propose an ambitious plan for companies in the social and solidarity economy, whose diversity must be guaranteed, and I would like to know why, Commissioner, you consider that it does not is not the time to do it, as you just said? The contributions are piling up, the Commission proposals fall far short of what we can expect. It is time to act for the social and solidarity economy. She deserves it.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: , on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the question put to the committee for the promotion of social economy enterprises, accompanied by a European action plan, calls for many comments, we will retain four of them: First, the economy social in principle appears to be a major and effective instrument in the fight against unemployment. In fact, many Europeans are gradually being left by the wayside. This state of affairs is undoubtedly one of the perverse effects of globalization in general, and of 70 years of European construction in particular, regardless of recurring economic crises. Each European country therefore has every interest in sustainably structuring its social economy according to its characteristics. Second, the development of a European action plan cannot be done without clearly defining the status of social enterprises. If we consider the French legal foundations, it is imperative that these companies meet four principles: 1) a goal other than profit sharing; 2) transparent and participatory governance; 3) management oriented towards the development of activities; and 4) legally indivisible reserves. The result is a very large number of jobs: 6% of French GDP, 8% of European GDP. This regulatory framework is accompanied, and there is the drift, with significant tax advantages, which paradoxically are very advantageous for the banking sector, mutuals, cooperatives, socio-educational and sports circles or healthcare distribution. . Very clearly, this drift thus reveals turnover of several tens of billions of euros in certain cases with, as has been said, colossal tax advantages. Everything must be done to avoid these abuses. Thirdly, the great social change in the world of work due to digitization and robotization which make this sector essential. here why each Member State should integrate it as one of its priorities and be inventive in all the forms it can take.Finally, it appears very clearly in our eyes that this is an area falling under the prerogatives of the sovereign state and that, by very definition, the desire to set up a European social economy amounts to creating another form.multinational, in this case multinationals employing only the poor.This is precisely the low-cost company we don't want.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 2014, here in Strasbourg, more than 2,000 social entrepreneurs launched an appeal to strengthen the role of the social economy in Europe. Three years later, it seems that this call has still not been heard and that the Commission is slow to come up with a real action plan for the social economy. We must therefore embrace the appeal launched in Strasbourg and support this form of economy which puts people at the center of the company's project. I wish to emphasize several points. First, on the importance of cooperatives in agriculture. The Commission must give producer organizations their full place in the new common agricultural policy in order to enable them to better defend and promote their products. Then I think we need to facilitate the financing of these business models. As such, I hope that the new social entrepreneurship fund, which we voted on a month ago, will help promote investments in this sector. Finally, in this digital age and the platform economy, we must be mindful of the false solidarity economy, which is collaborative in name only, and which in reality allows social regulations to be bypassed. I therefore look forward to the Commission’s proposals on the subject and hope that they will match the energy millions of Europeans are devoting to this more inclusive and sustainable economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I cannot understand how the Commission ignores the fact that 8% of European GDP and 14 million people working in the social economy deserve a consistent European action plan in synergy with the Member States.Let us never forget the synergy with what European regions, cities and municipalities in Europe can contribute, because they too can very much participate in the social economy.On the contrary, they participate, and some of my experiences speak in favor of how important it is for the state, and now I claim the European Union, to be involved in solving the problems in the social economy at the local and regional level.I will point out only one of them, because we do not have time, and that is the way of financing and enabling more favorable financing of such companies.I think that the Commission should play an important role here.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! The data shows that the social economy in the European Union is functioning well despite the economic crisis, the effects of which are still felt in some countries. This sector employs 14.5 million people and is responsible for 8% of the economic growth of the European Union. The social economy therefore generates jobs and, what is more, works for long-term social inclusion. The situation on the European market is improving. The level of unemployment has dropped significantly and there are countries in Europe where we deal with natural unemployment, and therefore one that cannot fall below the level. Unfortunately, the participation rate in many countries is still unsatisfactory, mainly for women, the elderly and people with disabilities. These people represent a huge potential that is still not sufficiently exploited in Europe. I am convinced that the social economy has developed instruments to activate these social groups. It's worth taking advantage of them. This will have a positive effect on the European economy as well as improve the level of social inclusion in Europe. It is therefore necessary to complement the new industrial strategy with an action plan for the social economy. That is why I join my colleagues' appeal to take action in this area as soon as possible.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Nilsson and colleagues from the Intergroup on Social Economy for this initiative.At the same time, I take this opportunity to thank Mr. Nilsson for not using the word neoliberal economy when speaking of a liberal economy, which is often used very inaccurately in my country, without a real insight into what it actually means.Of all the goals to be achieved by the European Social Economy Action Plan, social cohesion is the most important to me personally.I think that with the development of the modern world, and thus of the European Union, solidarity is being lost - both social solidarity and individual solidarity.That is why it is important to help those who need help in solidarity to take their place in society and in the world of work.I therefore fully support the views of colleagues and the parliamentary question, and I call on the Commission to start implementing the European Social Economy Action Plan as soon as possible.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I agree completely with the social economy model and I am glad my government does the same, and indeed they have a plan to extend it based on four foundations. Several Irish social enterprises work with marginalised members of our society, including persons with disabilities, to provide them with employment they cannot find elsewhere. During the summer I was pleased to attend what is called a ‘social farming enterprise’ where farmers invite people with disabilities on to their farm to work on a regular basis. This was on a farm in my own area, a cousin of my own, George Kelly from Beaufort, Co. Kerry. This is a great example of integrating people. One area where this could also work, especially in Ireland, is in the area of wind farms. There is opposition to wind farms now because many people feel that individuals are getting the profits but the whole of society has to carry the burden of noise, etc. which they associate with it; but if it was based on a social economy model then they would all benefit. I think that is something that we will really encourage and I am glad to say, as a rapporteur for renewable energy, that they were including local energy communities in the clean energy package. That certainly could be worthwhile. One area in which it was very successful in Ireland is the dairy co-ops. This is where farmers actually own the co-op, so the co-op works for the producers, the profits can be shared, they can come together to buy equipment etc., and it works extremely well. I think this is something we should be encouraging more. Thank you very much, and thanks to the Commissioner for her good words at the beginning.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Madam President, dear colleague Kelly - You spoke about your experience, or at least you spoke about how people with disabilities work in Ireland's social economy.I personally have a lot of experience with these people and I am interested in whether there are special benefits in Ireland for companies that employ more people with disabilities or are based mainly on doing business with people with disabilities, whether there are benefits in terms of lower taxes, somerelief - local, regional, national;is there something there or simply no such benefits?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is actually part of the plan by the government to extend the social model, so there would be tax breaks etc., and benefits for them. And indeed in the social economy, especially the social farming that I mentioned, the Minister has given it some financial help to encourage this and to expand it out further.  The answer is yes, but there is probably need for more. And when people see the benefits I think it would be easier to convince governments and others to put further finance there.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: - Madam President. Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank my colleague and friend Jens Nilsson for raising this issue. Because, to be honest, we in the European Parliament do not talk so often about the social economy, even though it is, in my view, one of the cornerstones. This is what distinguishes us and the European Union from others, from third countries. We always tend not to disturb the strong and help the weak. This is what is most important. The social economy is not a North Korean type or a planned economy like the USSR - I remember that from my childhood - or not something to share, and the like. The social economy is first and foremost a responsibility. Responsibility - and responsibility is not only on the part of the workers, but also on the part of the employers, and it is good that the Commission is working in this direction. I do not intend to criticize the Commission here, because I know how much the Commission has done to implement these plans.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your contributions to this important debate and also thank you Mr Nilsson for this question. If you allow me to be a little bit personal, I myself worked five years for the municipal office and I recognise very strongly that it is very important to develop the social economy at the local level – and not only at the local level – and to open the possibilities for people to start up entrepreneurial activities and keep them going.  I stressed at the beginning in the opening remarks that we, as the Commission, have fully recognised the importance of the European social model and of our social market economy. We recognise that the social economy is an instrument that brings solidarity and innovative answers to societal challenges that we face, and I also repeat again that the Commission has launched a number of new actions for the social economy as part of the 2016 communication on ‘Europe’s next leaders: the Startup and Scaleup Initiative’.  Let me stress again that we are focusing on five main pillars and actions, including: access to finance, access to markets, developing framework conditions and also using and developing new technologies and innovations. We will follow closely the developments of the social economy and social enterprises in Europe. We are committed to provide the appropriate policy for the social economy to help Europe achieve a more cohesive and inclusive society.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - The social economy has significant growth potential, as it already represents 8% of the European Union's GDP and employs 14.5 million people. It is therefore an essential lever for job creation and the fight against unemployment, which should obviously arouse our interest. I will nevertheless insist on the quality of the jobs created: in fact, certain French indicators point to an excessive use of so-called “atypical” jobs, that is to say precarious, as well as the proportions of executives and salaries below. the labor market average. To this already worrying situation, we should not add competition between Member States, which would have the effect of dragging wages and working conditions down. Unfortunately, this is what a European legal status for social enterprises could lead us to. In fact, in some states, especially in Eastern Europe, the social economy is still in its infancy. A European framework would be likely to create a demand for air, all the more so as public funds and tax advantages are sometimes at stake. Such an initiative is therefore as dangerous as it is inappropriate, employment remaining, moreover, a prerogative of the Member States.
